review_content: Brown red with a white head. Aroma is toasted dark bread, light chocolate, earthy and herbal. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter.
Pours an amber color. My go-to after work beer due to the great flavor and minor-league alcohol content. So far the best Dunkel style brew I've tried given local availability.
500 ml can. Pours clear dark brown color with beige head. Aroma of caramel and malt. The taste is malt, slightly sweetish, turning into bitterness from hops and roasted malt.
March madness 2021 - strong roasted flavor.  A little bitter.  Not my style
Clear dark brown w a thin, quickly dissipating head. Notes of coffee, burnt caramel and bread on the nose. Slight bitterness from the malt, light body. Not much of an after taste

Pours dark brown with a thin creme head. Aroma of caramel malt. Taste has sweetened malt notes, light coffee, toffee, toasted. Palate is watery, lingering roasted coffee notes, roasted malt on the nose. Good.
Balance of caramel and malt sweetness with slight toffee and coffee flavor.  Smooth, without bitterness.  Easy drinking for a dark beer.

33cl bottle at home.

Aroma: barely anything noticeable. A whiff of roasted malt maybe. Maybe I chilled it too much.

Appearance: dark brown but with a light in the background some beautiful autumn colors appear.

Taste: slight coffee bitterness but also chocolate sweetness. The malt is clearly noticeable.

Palate: despite having not much body, the sweetish aftertaste lingers for quite a while. Only a little bit of bitterness to compensate, but nicely balanced all the same.

Overall: pretty quaffable, nice and decent
Keg at Tugboat Brewery, Portland, OR on 18/08/2008.  A decent dunkel, with a fairly sweet, malty aroma.  Bready and lightly toasted malt flavours.

Copenhagen 11/1 2020. 50 cl can from Meny, Østerfælled Torv, Kbh. Ø. Warsteiner’s usual design on a dark brown background to signify it’s a Dunkel. Declaration about “the German Purity Law”. Why not use it for advertisement?

Pours clear, maroon with a red hue. Big off-white head. Settles as 2 cm thick, frothy layer of foam covering the surface of the beer.  Crawling up the sides of the glass. Moderate lacing.

Aroma is medium-intense, sweet, dark and roasted with a light nutty touch. Dark roasted malts, hints of brown sugar and caramel. Light odor of hazel nuts.

Medium strong carbonation. Thin, oily, lightly tingling texture.

Flavor has a strong sweetness followed by a medium strong bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet-ish. Lingers for a while. 

Decent macro dunkel which manages not to be too sweet and fairly well-balanced.
50 cl. can. A brown coloured beer with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, bread and with a roasted finish.

Light brown color, fast collapsing beige foamy head. 
Light aroma of rasted malts and some caramel. 
Taste is medium sweet, malty, some toffee and caramel. Light body, medium carbonation. Fairly good balance. An easy drinking, but nut so light dunkel. Not bad.
Sampled on tap at Brauhaus Schmitz, Pours a dark reddish brown color with a small to medium beige head. Nose and flavor are roast, dark fruit, raisins, grass, and florals. Lighter to medium bodied.

Pours a clear mahogany color.  One finger beige head.Okay retention and light lacing. 

Aroma is toasted malt.  Light toffee, medium figs. 

Taste is toasted barley.  Light toffee, light figs.  Mossy hops. 

Mouthfeel is light bodied.  Smooth, velvety.  Easy drinking.  Lightly dry with a  barely bitter finish. 

Overall, it’s good.  Solid brew.  Not at all overdone.  I would recommend it and would buy it again.

Bottle from Tenaya Lodge in Yosemite, CA. Aroma is light roasted malts, maybe some raisins. Taste is dark roasted malts, light cardboard and maybe some lightly toasted rye bread. Missing some of the dunk in dunkel 😉.
bottle @ auchan (budapest) brown colour, normal body, average carbonated, light brown head, caramel, roasted malty, toasty, bittersweet, easy to drink

Canned, 0.5 l.
Pours clear mahogany with a medium sized beige head on it.
Malty nose and aroma with caramel, toast and dough, taste of toffee.
Sweetbitter, toasty, mild hoppy finish.
Lara. Arooma: Toasty malty caramel grass. Ok palate. Flavour: Sweet like, toatsy maltiness and toasty caramel, fair. Thin like but ok.

0,5l can. Clear brown colour with quickly disappearing white head. Aroma: Caramel, honey with a hint of yeasty and boozey tones. Taste: Has a short malty sweet start with a quite sourish rye-like tone and mouthfeel without any bitter feel. A little bit watery too. Light body with fizzy carbonation. Medium lasting fading sourish finish.

0,33 bottle. Color light-chestnut brown, translucent, practically absent head, although filled in a suitable glass at a suitable temperature. Aroma of coffee, earthy, slightly sweet caramels, dry. The taste of quality roasted German malt is sweet, full-bodied, coffeey, juicy, burnt with sugar, and even a little bitter. It looked worse than it tasted, though it was a little wet.
***
 Szín világos- gesztenye barna, áttetsző, habja gyakorlatilag nem volt, pedig megfelelő pohárba, megfelelő hőfokon került kitöltésre. Illata kávés, földes, picit édeskés karamelles, száraz. Íze a minőségi pörkölt német malátától édes, telt, kávés, zamatos, égetett cukros, és még picit keserű is. Kinézetre rosszabb volt, mint ízre, bár picikét azért vizes.

Dark Brown (Tea)
Nose. Caramel, toasted bread and a bit of hops.
Taste. The beer body is velvety, pleasant. The taste is malt, slightly sweetish, turning into bitterness from hops and roasted malt.
atom. antis. pörkölt malátás illat és ízvilág. mégis könnyű, vizes test, marha jó ivódunkel.
De geur is lekker fruiting. Normale schuimkraag. De smaak is verrassend goed. Best te drinken

Ar: Grass, hay, and some toasted malt; herbal hops. Ap: Chestnut and crystal clear; medium light tan head with good retention, settling into a solid cap of foam. T: Toast and steel; hay, chalk and light coffee; bitterness is low; herbal hop flavor; clean fermentation profile; finish is lightly toasted malt and more coffee. M: Light body with high carbonation; finish is very dry. O: A quaffable, clean dark lager; lots of hay, herbal hop notes, and steely malt.
Pours dark brown with light head that fades quickly; sweet roasting aromas on the nose; mild, off dry, bitter finish. I like it despite the reviews and mass production brewery!

clear mahogany Brown colour, half inch of creamy beige head; aroma of burnt sugar, ash, some burnt plum jam and some honeycomb toffee; taste of toasted rye bread, some slight burnt plum jam and burnt bittenrness; not bad
Can. Pours cocacola brown minimal head. Barley, grain, toast, caramel aroma. Mild toast, grain, caramel syrup flavor. Dry bread finish. Decent enough.
A great display of what a Dunkel should taste like. Light malty, toasty and smooth. If you like the style and you want an easy drinker at a reasonable price go with Warsteiner.

There isn’t anything particularly “special” or “innovative” about this dunkel but it is a very good beer representative of its species. It is very toasty and biscuity, smooth and not sour, has a slight zing. This is liquid bread. Prost. This is my go to dunkel at a good price. Brings back memories of backpacking Germany.
A little on the toasty end for me. Body is nice. Fair moth feel. No ral linger taste. Avoids being overly sweet but lacks a little malt depth.
Tap @ BOT. Light brown coloured. Toasted, sweet, bit of coffee, hint of citrus.
De barril. Bock alemana. Color marron rojizo. Dulce. Retrogusto agradable ligeramente amargo.

From draft, this is a malty dark bet with quite a creamy body. Nice smooth Dunkel with no harsh edges.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
smooth simple creamy dunkel. if these arent too expensive then its a pretty good buy. very drinkable and nothing bothering me about it
Bottle. It poured a reddish brown color with a thin tan head.  It has a malty aroma with caramel and toffee notes. It is slightly sweet and a bit dry. Nice.
Pours clear mahogany with medium, off white head. Aroma is light caramel and light earthiness. Taste is caramel, warming to roast. Finish is malty. A decent dunkel.

Bottle stamped enjoy by 8/3
A: Clear dark tea color with quickly falling tan head and spotty lace.
S: Sweet roasty scent with faint chocolate.
T: Again sweet hints of chocolate and roasted malt with light lingering tartness from herbal or leafy hops. 
M: Very thin texture even for 4.9% with lively carbonation and watery finish.
O: Not bad, especially for a Euro-lager. I'd buy again in a pinch.
Brune trouble, légère mousse. Nez malté un peu toasté et noisette.Gout pareil, malté avec de note noisette puis caramel .Corps moyen, fin avec légère amertume .

This is a very good beer. I usually drink this straight from the bottle, as finding it on tap is uncommon to say the least. Flavour is well balanced, though not as hardy as I'd ideally like. Overall a very good buy.
Keg at Bru, Philly. Dark brown with a thin white head. Coffee aroma, flavour is crisplager and coffee. Not the best dunkel I've had

Dark brown/amber color surprising for a lager
Refreshing mouth feel
Semi sweet lager taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Shijonawate AEON Mall liquor shop. Nose of roast malt, mild coffee. and cocoa. Clear dark brown with red-tinged edges, thin tan head. Light roastiness, caramel, a bit nutty, some dried dark fruit, cocoa, and gentle bitterness.Thin body. Fairly tasty and very mild all around.

Saturday, December 02, 2017	11:09 PM	
11.2 ounce bottle poured to wine glass	
Sight: brown, small ran foam that quickly goes away	
Smell: aroma of roated malts, fragrant	
Taste: low bitterness, some sweetness	
Mouthfeel: lively carbonation, medium follow through	
Overall: very good beer, repeat: yes look for: no
Pours a dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is dark and roasted. Taste is malty but not overly sweet. Clean in the finish. Well done

ok, ok, this might have too much malt?????????

A very "thick" tasting beer that is good warm or cold. Nice taste, but the malt is significant, even for me. Now I understand the reason Germans call Dunkels "liquid bread".

7/2021 update - not my fav, too malty in all the wrong ways, reduced rating to get it off my list.

Botella presentación de 330 ml. Cerveza tipo Dunkel, color marrón oscuro. Aroma con intensos puntos de chocolate y café particularmente. en cuanto al sabor es una mirada profunda a su aroma, con un amargo final que denota la falta de forma de la cerveza. Agradable para ciertos momentos y/o paladares, pero le falta un escalón más para codearse con otras cervezas de su clase.

Draught at Town Crier. Quite nice chocolate brown with a white head. The aroma of this is quite terrible, smelling of weird roasted stinky socks (really hard to describe). Happily it tastes much better than it smells. Roasted malt and caramel flavours, not a lot of depth. OK.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Greg & Jane's Beer and Wine. Appearance is clear, dark red with nice sparkle, 1/2 finger-width beige head with poor retention and spotty lacing. Aroma is nice roasted malts, like lightly burned toast, dark chocolate. Taste is roasted malts, light chocolate and earthy European hops. Palate is light-to-medium bodied with thin texture, soft-to-average carbonation and dry finish as taste. Overall, a nice, crisp, lightly sweet treat.
very good healthy body of coffee and chocolate.drank it out bottle wish I would have used a glass to inspect color and lacing, but I don't taste color.

a decent beer. A bit thin and boring if compared to others. A bit on the watery side. But a pretty good beer for the cheep price

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The absolute best beer I’ve ever had. Rich, smooth, full bodied taste that is refreshing as well as satisfying.

Vroeguh kon je van die fusten Warsteiner kopen. Je sloeg een gat boven in de 5 liter fust en dan liep vanzelf het bier zuiver op luchtdruk naar beneden uit het tapkraantje in je glas. Grootste nadeel was als het fust te lang open stond het bier uiteindelijk dood was. En dat proefde je als je te lang wachte.  Nu 2017 met een blikje proef ik exact dezelfde smaak. Maar van bier wat al dood geslagen is??? Bier is dus niet zo goed als ik me herinner. :-( schuimt goed ziet er met een iets donkere pils kleur leuk uit. Maar smaakt gewoon beroerd. Je proeft de mout en lichte bitterness maar ook helaas de smaak alsof het biertje al een paar uur staat. Hierdoor absoluut geen doordrink biertje wat ik vroeger hiermee wel deed. Lag misschien toch vroeger niet aan die fust maar was het bier gewoon niet mijn smaak...
Good Overall beer. Taste is roasted malt, and a little coffee. Beer is easy to drink and has a good feel on the palate. Good beer overall, and an easy to drink dark beer.

Draft at Epcot in "Germany". Dark, almost opaque brown with cream colored head. Dark roasted malt aroma. Notes of caramel and chocolate. Taste and aroma grow more intense and improve as it warms.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Brown with a thin white head. Very chocolatey but not much else going on. Also a bit thin.

A decent lager. Aroma is faint. Medium body with dark brown coloring, small lacing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Average light beer, not disappointing yet, no surprise. Still, worth a try.
Brown pour, thin head. Aroma of roasted malts. The flavor is similar, roasted malts, a little burnt. Light body. Toasted oat flavor.

330 ml bottle bought at Gorgeous Wine & Cigar in Yuen Long.



Clear amber copper colour; One quarter finger head with soapy white foam which fades in 30 seconds; Good sticky lacing with barely notable slight carbonation; Quite fragrant aroma of malt, with caramel, strong toffee, cardboard, dark fruits, light chocolate, floral, icing sugar, bread and fair grass; Close to light sweet taste of dark malt, with red fruits, light caramel, light toast, floral, very light molasses, biscuits, light lemon, very light bitter hops and grass; Light body. Watery palate; Mouth feel is fair dark maltyness in very thin background. A bit like English Ale with basic red fruityness and light caramel with fair touches of toasts. Floral with light sweetness. Biscuity with very light lemon to round. Fairly good!... Hoppiness is floral and fair grass in nose, same in taste with light lemon; Bitterness is very light for an abrupt, low astringent light toast finish; Fairly dry after taste. Fruity and fairly easy to mouth.



Comments: This one’s aroma suggest a pretty sweet Dunkel, yet the taste is a low-sweet, simple dark lager which taste more like an English Ale than Dunkel. Clean, easy and competent, drinkable but unexciting.

Poured into a lager glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt dark amber close to brown color with a thin finger’s worth of white foamy head that dissipated immediately. Some light stringy lacing glosses along the sides of the glass.
The aroma starts off with a sweet bready to red delicious apples blending upon subtle tones of cocoa powder.
The flavor embraces the bready sweet malts initially and then brings about the apples and cocoa. Nice semi-sticky bready sweet aftertaste yielding to a refined sliding finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a nice sessionability about it. Low carbonation. Clean lager smoothness rolls over my tongue.
Overall, an absolutely wonderful Munich Dunkel lager that I would love to have again, preferably with its food.

From the 330 ml. bottle with an expiration date of 25 Feb 2017. Handsome chestnut-mahogany brown pour with a tremendous and fluffy tan head. The aroma is very roasted with a vibrant caramel malt, toasted brown bread, and sweet character and a low to no hop profile. The body is light. The taste seems less sweet than the aroma suggests but it ends fairly clean. Easy drinker for the October season.

At the 2016 Dayton Octoberfest. Pours dark brown with a thick thick foam with tiny bubbles. Caramel dry cocoa initial cold crisp. Wonderful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Keg @ Gasthof, Minneapolis. Deep reddish / chestnut pour with a small off-white head. Nose has some gentle toasted malt. A bit of caramel. Fairly sweet flavor. Caramel and some toasted malt. Bready. A bit tired / muted. Fairly light body, spritzy carb. Overall, a fairly middle of the road effort.

Bière brune aux reflets rouge-orangées, parfaitement limpide, effervescence moyenne-faible, et surmontée d’un col beige moyennement large et moyennement dense, et qui se réduit tout doucement. Arômes de grain rôti, beaucoup de noisettes, avec odeurs particulièrement terreuses, marrons grillés, feuille morte, tourbe… Effluves également un peu sucré, tendance caramel. Arômes aussi assez fumés, un peu charcuterie, davantage charbon de bois, herbe brûlée... Enfin, odeur également quelque peu épicée, clou de girofle, poivre… et même subtile vanille. Nez fort agréable et intéressant, complexité et intensité assez élevées. En bouche, pétillement plutôt faible sur la langue, onctuosité moyenne au palais. Au goût, comme le nez l’annonçait, c’est très «grain rôti» avec nuances assez évidentes de noisettes, terre, marrons grillés, etc… Le malt est donc principalement céréalier, présentant tout de même un léger sucré de type caramel/cassonade. Saveur également un peu fumée (mais peut-être moins qu’au nez…) à tendance tourbe, boisé et herbes brûlées. Quelques épices aussi en bouche, surtout du poivre. Enfin, saveur de houblon plutôt herbacé, en route vers une finale à l’amertume de faible à modérée. Très bel équilibre malt/houblon, très bonne intégration des différentes saveurs entre elles, intensité élevée en bouche, bonne complexité. Il s’agit d’une bien bonne bière!
Clean lager, malty with caramel, bread, dark fruits. Complex and light, really nice beer to drink.
Tap at Swan Market. Medium amber-brown, medium head. Light caramel and chocolate nose with a bit of earth. Medium sweetness, lightly hopped. Light body. Ok.

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with a cream-colored head. Aroma of malt and roast. Taste is dark bread, roasted malts, coffee, hazelnut, and chocolate notes. It definitely exceeded my expectations.

Dark brown clear colour, medium tan head. Aroma has malts, chestnuts and wheatbread. Taste is sweet and sour, well balanced between both. Has a strong licorice sensation, aftertaste is strong on the bitter side, some hints of malt and molases. Light body, thin texture. Very strong for a 4.9% ABV, good with a steak.

draft and plenty of it..poured a darker cola colored almost brown. sweet malts and caramel on the nose hints of chocolate as well. standard dunkel if you like them which I do. the flavor is nothing spectacular but it is good. plenty of medium bodied malt and caramel and chocolate...easy to drink.

500 ml can. Coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Pours dark brown with a medium sized frothy head and good carbonation. Coffee and dark chocolate with wood and nutty notes. Very dry texture. Sweet malt finish. Not bad.
dark brown color with thin head that dissipates quickly. aroma is dark roasted malts. flavor is roasted malt, dark grain bread, and a hint of coffee.

500 ml can from Dunmore Liquor, served in a curved pint. Pours a reddish-cola shade with generous, fine, slow carbonation and a tan head that retreats to just a thin cap, leaving islands of lace. Aroma is primarily brown sugar-sweetened toasty malt with a buttery, cinnamony hint, fragrant red berries, and a faint herbal hop. Flavor-wise, the toasted malt surges forth, leaving the caramel sweetness in its wake, and hints of coffee, cocoa, charcoal, and smoke follow as the sip ends. The herbal hop hides among the roasted elements. Medium body, with a brief, pleasant lingering of the toastiness. This is a nice, soft, yet tasty dunkel that could serve as an introducing to darker beers like schwarzbier, imperial stouts, and the like.
bottle // aroma: roasted barley and sunflower seeds. taste: roasted barley, black bread crust.
Pours in dark ruby color with medium size head. Aroma of fresh dark bread, cereal, roasted notes. Lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Light body, thin feel, low canonization, light bitter aftertaste
Pretty decent. Has a nice toast malt aroma. Taste is a nice chocolate and roasted malt, good body, easy drinking.

Draft at Bru Craft. Clear very dark copper brown pour with a quickly diminishing foamy head. Aroma somewhat muted when cold but tastes like a (albeit a bit too shallow) proper German Dunkel. Gently dark toasted pale malts. Notes of bramble berry, sweet breads, liquorice, liver, pumpernickel, black plums, olives, ouzo, smoked meat. Great notes but none is strong enough to feel over the top. Not the best Dunkel but a truly great Dunkel.

On tap, poured a clear brown hue w/ small diminishing head. Moderate roasty coffee aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light to moderate bitter finish. Tastes are almond skins, medium roast breakfast blend coffee, hazelnut and light brown sugar notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear reddish brown tea colored with a thin white ring. Slightly oily texture with clingy lacing. Nice strong aroma of sweet barley malts. Body is very light and thin but flavor is very refreshing and tasty. Tastes like toast. Nicely toasted, not over roasted.
On Tap at Prost, Boise Rich deep amber/brown. Toasted malt sweetness and a smooth mellow finish.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with little white head. Aroma is of wheat, liqiourice, roasted malts and grapes. Tastes of chocolate, wheat, liqiourice, and light plum. Has a smooth light body with average carbonation and a light chocolate aftertaste.

(333ml bottle, Beijing) Aroma: Nice nose of coffee, malt, wood. Appearance: rich brown color, off-white thick head. Taste: Coffee, grass, herbs, a bit medicinal, barrel, roasted, burnt. Palate: Quite sparkly on the tongue, crisp, tight, dry, lingering bitterness on the cheeks. Overall: Interesting beer with a decent amount of flavor and character. Not as malty as some of the heavy duty Dunkels, but that is almost a good thing. Quite roasty tasting.

Pours a clear cola robe topped by a timid coarse whitish head showing low retention and lacing properties. Carbonation is medium. Nose is sweet dark bread with toasted nuts. Some burnt notes of barley. Very brothy backbone, tough. Taste is nutty and sweet. Dark bread, grassy hops, faint sour, medium body and quite sharp on the tongue. Medium toasted and grassy finish. Not bad. Cheers!

On tap at Germany in Disney world. Nice and dry easy to drink.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Escura, espuma de média duração. Aroma de malte tostado, um pouco de chocolate e caramelo proeminentes, bem convidativos, o ponto forte. Na boca, é crocante e com sabor de malte tostado, pão, caramelo e notas de fermeto, textura e corpo bem leves. Alta drinkabilidade
Bottle in Munich. Dark copper body. Nose is grassy, toasty. Taste is malts, toasty, sweet. Light bodied. Pretty good.
Nice! Dark pour with a foamy head. Nice chocolatey flavour with malts backing them up.

Drank alone from 12oz bottle. Thick frothy light brown head which stays fairly well. Color is transparent, sierra brown. Taste includes some sourness but mostly malty rye turning to roastedness to then turn watery. A type of beer which makes you wonder why they import this from Germany when Northwest, California, Colorado, Dogfish Head, etc Beer is so good from America. 3.75 BD.

Aroma: roasted sunflower seed, oil, some funky notes.
Taste light sweetness, low bitterness, light sourness.
Flavour: roasted black bread, unrefined sunflower oil.

Not bad for macro.

BOTTLE 33 CL. Clear chestnut brown, beige head. Warm toasted bread aroma, a little oily, fecal and spicy. The taste is clearly toasted bread crust, slightly sweet with notes of almond/marzipan. The finish is light bitter with roasty and spicy hoppy notes. Regular lager body with average carbonation. Pretty nice.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle poured into a brandy snifter. The beer is a clear, dark brown with a grey head of foam. Decent retention. The aroma has some burnt toast character, and a nutty, toffee-like nuance. The taste has moderate sweetness levels. There is a touch of bitterness at the very end. Lighter in body and medium to high carbonation.
330 ml bottle. Dark brown colour with small head. Aroma is bready and roasty with same taste. Medium body with soft carbonation. Surprisingly enjoyable.

Tasted from draft. Pours a clear dark brown/ruby. Aroma is nutty. Taste is moderately sweet with minimal to no bitterness. Flavors of roasted nuts, caramel, biscuits, toffee. Above average dunkel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Taste of roasted malts, nutty, with some hops.
Mostly clear dark brown in color.
Malty complex nose, medium body.
On tap at Gustavs. Pours a dark brown color with a medium white head. A big chocolate toast nose. Dark caramel, toasted malts, a light chocolate base. Soft. Easy.

Dunkel alemã apresenta coloração escura avermelhada,creme bege volumoso e duradouro,aroma suave de café,sabor de malte torrado,café,ameixa seca,bem refrescante.Faltou um pouco de ¨corpo¨pelo estilo,mas é uma boa cerva.
Malted barley aroma. Taste is a bready roasted barley, light honey, and some crisp earthy hops.
11.2 oz. bottle. Pours cola colored with small quickly diminishing off white head. Aroma of roasted malts and pine. Taste was sweet, roasted grains and coffee.
Great for a cheap beer at $6 for a six pack of bottles. Reddish brown when poured into a pint glass. The mouth feel was like Busch but tasted much better.
11.2 oz bottle pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and grain. Taste is roasted malts, coffee and grains.
Chocolate all over it. Smooth, thick body. Really beautiful lager. I like it a lot. Best thing I’ve had at this hilaripus Oregon Oktoberfest.

Dark brown with a good beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, dates. Light-medium bodied, slightly creamy mouthfeel, well balanced on the palate with a malty finish. Taste is dark malt, chocolate, caramel, dates. Tasty.

Poured from an 11.2 OZ bottle into a pint glass. 
The aroma is full of malt and is very nice.
Appearance- The beer pours a clear dark brown with a small white head.
Taste- The flavor is malty with a nice smooth texture.
Overall- A nice Munich Dunkel Lager. I would drink this again.

Love the aroma of roasted barley in this. Dark, rich amber color. Taste of barley not bad, but a little lighter taste than expected. Slight bitter finish. Would pair perfect with brats and other German meats. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap (several ’samples’). 
Amazing I haven’t rated this beer before given that it was a staple in my beer supply last century before the coming of the craft beer revolution.

With a clear mahogany body and a decent head this is not only good looking, but good tasting as well. That’s a little reassuring given my history with this beer even though, to be honest, this was heavily influenced by price back in the day.
Plenty of toffee and medium malt with enough hops to give this a fairly neutral bitter-sweet balance.
Some darker malts too and just a hint of smoke.
Very nice.
Botella. Dorada. Aroma cereal. En boca resulta refrescante pero con un toque amargo más marcado de lo normal. Bien. Poco más.

Rated based on notes taken 29 Sep 2012 -- Ahhh this brings me back to college. I used to drink Warsteiner all the time! A decent German example of a Dunkel. There’s better out there, but this one will do.
Light bodied aroma of malt, oat, nuts, vegetables. Flavor is chocolate, malt, caramel and oak. Fine beer.
Pours reddish brown with a off white head. Notes of caramel and toffee. Taste of coffee, toffee malts and bread. Good Beer. Will have again.
Pours a yellow colour no head or lacing. Slight malty aroma. Light malt taste with a little citrus hop taste. It’s OK, as a lawn mower beer.

Pours dark red to brown with a white head. Aromas of malt and caramel. Taste is slightly complex with taste of the same with, toast, vanilla. Nice lager nothing special but worth a buck for a 16 oz can.

Nothing flashy here, but a solid dark lager, one that the States just can’t seem to get right. Chestnut color with thin white head. Smooth caramel/toffee malt light bodied, a bit nutty, faint floral hops. Refreshing for a dark beer.

500 ml can, poured into a mug at ~40 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours a clear hickory brown, and forms a thick, fluffy head of pale off-white foam with good retention. Lacing is decent.

Smell: Bread, mild toffee, and something vaguely floral waft out of the glass.

Taste: See "Smell". The taste opens with bread and mild toffee, with hints of faint light caramel. That is joined by some floral and spicy notes as the beer moves along, and the aftertaste is a lingering mix of all of the above.

Mouthfeel: Thin and light-bodied, without ever quite getting all the way to watery.

Overall: A decent Munich dunkel, especially for the price point I paid for this batch of $1 per half-liter!
A decent beer if you are a little short of cash. Quickly disappearing head.Fair malt taste a little caramel. Aroma a bit metallic.
Bottle. Clear amber brown color, medium light tan head. Aroma of caramel. Taste is lightly toasted nutty caramel. Plain.

Transfer from BA review on 10-25-12- 

 Poured from bottle into pint glass

 Appearance – Pours a mahogany color with some quite nice red highlights. The off-white head formed upon pouring was quite large and had a moderate level of retention. The fading head in the end gave way to a medium amount of lacing.

 Smell – The aromas were sweet and fruity. They were heaviest of a sweet cherry and apple smell, but also contained a light roasted bready and a light hop smell.

 Taste – The taste starts out of a bready, cherry and a lighter roasted flavor. The roasted flavors begin growing stronger after the initial taste. These mix with some flavor of a toast flavor and more cherry as the taste advances further. In the end, these flavors, when mixed with the a lighter earthy hop taste, leave a interesting bitter taste on the tongue (I can’t decide if I like it or not).

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is just a tad above average in terms of creaminess and thickness for a brew of only 4.8%. It also has just a slightly lower than level carbonation. These two qualities are quite nice for the roasted flavors of the brew and help accentuate the fruit and roasted flavors.

 Overall – A pretty good brew with some nice fruit and roasted flavors. While tasty it maintains a fairly high level of drinkability. Not too shabby.

Bottle: Dark brown, old & woody looking with a very faint red-ish tint. Good clarity, voluptuous beige cap that grows huge & sticks around. Big Munich malt aroma... Caramel, toast, bread, dough, light cocoa powder, mild cookie dough reminders, clean lager yeast finish. Slight twinge of metallic toffee, roast, & nuts. God, I’m loving the nose on this one... Pure, fresh, clean. Sadly, the taste is underwhelming in comparison. Watered down, thick bouts of heavy yeast with a big chalky, mineral backdrop. Grainy, much lighter caramel & dough-y presence on the palate. Light toast, big diacetyl finish, like buttery popcorn kernels. Where the hell did this fall apart? Good mouth feel for the style but the taste just kills things. Not sure how the aroma is so nice, but this just falls apart on the tongue.

Taste of caramel, toast, biscuit, chocolate, nuttiness, herbal, earth, and light pepper.  Lingering notes of chocolate, caramel, toast, nuttiness, and herbal on the finish for a short bit.  Fairly dry and a touch thin on the finish.  Fair amount of flavor and robustness; no cloying at all after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a lightly creamy and fairly crisp mouthfeel that is good.  No alcohol presence in the taste or finish.  Overall this is a very solid dunkel.  A touch thin and watery; but has some nice flavors, balance, and is extremely easy to drink.  Enjoyable stuff.

Draft@Crest Hotel, Prince Rupert, Canada.  Blackish beer with a relatively strong head.  The aroma is malty and yeasty, and the flavour is bitter with a reasonable amount of maltiness and yeastiness.  Overall a pretty average dunkel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location/Date:Draft on September 15th, 2012.



Appearance: Pours a dark black. 
 

Aroma: Aroma of light roast.
 

Taste: Caramel, roasty malts, somewhat sweet.
   

Palate: Light body.



Summary: Decent German dunkel, nice amount of sweetness.

Dark, thin bodied, with minimal head.  Roasted malts on first sniff.  Light coffee, roasted malt on finish only.  The water thin body was a turn off for me with most of the flavors happening on the finish.  Not a favorite.

Very dark but with no kick. If you are a beer this dark you need to bring it on the finish and this does not. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml can from NSLC.  Pours a clear reddish dark brown with fairly large khaki-coloured head.  Aroma is grassy, sweet grains and a little dark malt.  Flavour is bready, light choclate and a bit of grassiness.  Pretty macro taste, but with at least little dunkel-like character.

Aroma: bread, biscuit. Appearance: a dark amber/brown with a mostly diminishing ivory head and minimal lacing. Taste: malt forward - bready with hints of sweetness. No hop bitterness. Mouthfeel: medium-light to medium bodied with minimal carbonation. Creamy. Overall: very drinkable - smooth.  Invites more rounds.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bière brune de 4.8 % d’alcool. Elle possède un odorat sucré et un moyen col au versement, d’unecoluleur opaque. Elle possède un beau goût sucré, céréalier, de houblon en finale. Légèrement prenant en fin de bouche. Goûteuse et ample en bouche. Très bonne !
Malty and sweet, dark color.  Very drinkable, my friend that only drinks bud light loved it.  But it’s a bit pricey, although I did enjoy this one a lot
Very nice dark amber color, but head is not there for a 5/5. Smells bitter and of dark malts.  Taste is of roasted dark malts, maybe some molasses.  Palate is a bit thin.  Overall, a good beer.
pours a nice golden brown, nice malty flavor with a touch of sweetness.  Good but nothing noteworthy.
Draft - Malty bread, maybe some rye.  Clear burgundy with thin head.  Malt, caramel, brown sugar and very minuscule bitterness.  Refreshing, but too sweet for me.
12 ounce bottle pours a dark brown color, aroams of toasted malt, light wheat, and some grain.  Flavors follow suit, a macro dunkel.
Nice clean German dark beer.  Although its not really dark, so it has a very drinkable taste.
Bottle to pint. Looks fine; like a macro dunkel. Smells and tastes okay; malty. Average on the palate. I prefer the Verum.

From notes: Poured clear red-amber with a 2-finger greyish-white head.  Aroma of caramelly malt mixed with some yeast.  Body is medium-to-thin.  Finish is brief and a touch dry.  Caramel malt flavor with a grainy note that appears as it warms.
Warsteiner, to me, is a generic dark beer. The flavor is decent, but I don’t get too excited about drinking it.
Bottle pour into plastic cup. Slight malty sweetness on nose. Smooth with no carbonation on palate. Very middle of the road on bitterness, malt, hops, but I guess that is typical for a dunkel.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of roasted and toasted cereal malts, caramel, bread and grass hops.  Dark brown hue with an average off-white head that mostly diminished and left ok lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and bitter.  Palate is light bodied and watery average.  Overall an okay roasty brew.

On tap, served in a plastic cup at Christy’s in Cincinnati (they refused to give glasses on the outdoor patio). Clear darker color. Minimal tan head, lots of lace. Smooth carbonation, dry texture. Nice, mildly smokey aroma - some peanut butter, mild bitter taste, a little bite. My friend Robby has a sip, found it to be "bitter". Toasted malts, some chocolate? Nutty. Decent.. Moderately interesting, but can’t call it tasty. Bit flat too, not in a good way. Kind of disappointing.

weird big head dark cherry red carbinaton smells like light skunk(road kill,cannabis)chocolate coffee in a diff way. hops hurt belly taste is water chocolate barly kinda like corn syrup taste like in dragon stout. its okay

Pours golden yellow   Yeast. Bread. Pepper. Very drinkable crisp and clean
Slight bitterness. Some roasted nuts. Good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

So, I’ve always kinda complained about how Warsteiner is a shitty example of German beer. Especially the Dunkel. But upon my last tasting, it started to grow on me a bit. Maybe it took pouring it into a nice clear stein to see it’s mahogany, oaky, copper color and nicely sustaining frothy white head.  The aroma is rather nice too; very sweet and malty with caramel and a hint of cocoa.  The flavor is the only thing that is left to be desired next to a higher quality dunkel.  Yet it is still flavorful enough to enjoy while being rather light and refreshing.  Cocoa and vanilla with roasted malts.  Nice, medium finish.  Not too shabby.  But no Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel..

Appearance: Pours a chocolate amber with a thin head that doesn’t provide any appreciable lacing.
Aroma: Faint smell of wet hay, malt and dried fruit.
Taste: Mild taste with notes of toasted malt and mild citrus hops notes.
Texture: Crisp and dry with decent carbonation.
Drinkabilty: Too mild with little character.  I would like to see more coffee and hops.
Presentation: Poured from a 12oz bottle in to a Pilsener glass.

I have fond memories of Wasteiner at the little supermarket near my first apartment with the larger bottles a flip-off ceramic cap. It’s been so long that I’m not even sure that it their Dunkel that came that way, but those bottles made their way into my first homebrew experiment. (The metal clip doesn’t necessarily hold the cap on when the bottle wants to explode.)
Anyway, back to the Dunkel. Tried again recently on tap. Pours a nice brown color. Aroma had a little fruit in it. Smooth, with caramel and malts. More sour than I prefer, though the bitter and sweet try to balance out the sourness. 
An OK beer, if there’s nothing else available.

Tasted from 330ml bottle into nucleated pint glass. It poured a clear, dark reddish brown color with short-lived tan head, no lace. Mild aromas of toast, faint noble hops, very faint black pepper and sulfur from lager yeast. Flavors were very neutral for such a dark beer: just a little toast again and  nutty tannins, but no complex malt sweetness, melanoidins, fruity esters, phenols, etc. Light body, average carbonation, mellow mouthfeel with clean finish. Boring but not bad. I realize this is a famed German import, and I suppose it’s a true-to-style Munich dunkel, but I’ve had far better examples.
UPDATE JAN 2, 2014: sampled again, this time a little better head retention and lace, and a few more hints of pils malt and grassy noble hops, but it was still such a subdued overall impression, with a very weak and watery mouthfeel.

Can 500 ml. Bought at SAQ. Pours dark red with copper reflect. Aroma: nuts, roasted malt, caramel. Taste is the same. Sweet beer, with a slight bitterness. Strange aftertaste. Dry on palate. Ok beer. Refreshing. Not highly drinkable.

330ml bottle pours dark brown in color with a finger of off-white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing behind.  Aroma is slightly nutty with some caramel and grass.  Taste is light caramel malty sweetness with a little bit of nut and a light hop bitterness.  A decent dunkel style brew that is easy to drink and somewhat tasty.

Tap. Poured a clear brown with a big frothy khaki head. Smell is bread biscuit, light banana, clove, and malt. Taste is bread, rye, biscuit, malt, light spice, and a touch of banana. Thick body with medium carbonation. Not my favorite Dunkel by any means, but still decent.

Nice head, bigger than I expected. Dark hazelnut. Smooth palate. Very mild skunkiness mixed with a light nutty flavour mixed with the German malt. Not a "huge" beer but one I appreciate and could easily sip and enjoy on a crisp early autumn day in the forest.
Aroma is grain, malts, and yeast.  Pours golden brown with a big off white head.  Taste is malty and grain with a little bit of hops.  Pretty good.

Cherry wood color with off-white head.  Aroma is seawater with low salinity, black olives, oats, fish and oyster.  Taste is slighty swwet, bitter on the way down.  Maybe a little toasty malt going on.  Average carbonation and maybe a bit oily.  Overall not bad, but based on the scent it puts off I really want to do it with fish and chips or oysters.
Notes from way back in 2008. Pours dark with about a finger of head. Aroma of caramel and light hops. Taste is about the same. Not too bad. Nothing special here but I’ll drink it.

Poured from one of those metric 12oz bottles into a pint glass.  Nein date on zee bottle.  Pours a very pretty medium dark brown with a tinge of purple.  Good frothy whiteish/very light brown head and a spot of lacing.  Aroma is light and mildly sweet but not very discernible.  Mouthfeel is very light with just the right amount of carbonation. Taste is very light with some charcoal, chalk, dirt, berries and fudge.  And of course there’s a massive metallic aftertaste, ech!  Meh, not a great or even decent beer at all.  If I could try it on tap at a place where I knew it’d be fresh, I’d try it again.  Otherwise, forget it.

Pour from a 11.2 oz bottle. Clear brown brew with off white head - looks like a cola. Aroma of bitter roasted wheat. Taste is sour roasted grains with sour dry finish. Wet cardboard in the aftertaste. Ok.

Where did I have this? Location not in my notes, though I suspect J. Betski’s, Raleigh. At any rate, a pretty unassuming medium brown lager. Vibrantly carbonated, which certainly helps. Nose is dingy malts, a touch of yeast, and some sweet treats.  Some more balance in the flavors, with bitter hops providing a contrast with the caramel malts and so forth. Decent.

Faint whispers of burnt sugar, bread, caramel, roasted barley, and a bit of papaya in the aroma. Watery and almost decently carbonated palate. The taste is a bit more roasted than the aroma suggests, with decent bitterness and sweetness. Pleasing and drinkable.
Light bodied and thin on the tongue. Looks a lot bolder than it tastes. Malty, sour aftertaste that fades slowly on the tastebuds.

500 ml can. Pours a clear orange brown with a nice beige head. Tastes like chocolate, caramel, roasted and nuts. Very little bitterness. Body is quite light. Was okay, but not super and I feel I paid way too much money for what I got.
Fuck guiness. You want a bold tasting brew that wont fill you up and never let you down. Here it is.
Pours deep brown and crystal clear.  Slightly off white and long lasting head.  Bready toasty malty.  I do enjoy a dunkel and this one is decent.

500ml can from LCBO. Ruby brown with a generous biege head that quickly settles. Lots of sweet malt, grains, somewhat thin; sweet on the palate, body is lacking with low carbonation, becomes a little dry but remains sweet on the finish. M’eh.

Clear dark amber with a persistent off-white head covering and frothy lace that slowly drops back into the glass.  Starts as malt, adds caramel through the palate adding a light hop finish to balance.  Nothing great, but very drinkable.

A decent, cheap beer to go to when there aren’t many options. A general crowd-pleaser for parties, etc. Flavor and body is good enough to go down easy when necessary but not good enough to buy otherwise.
Slightly malty, sweet aroma.  Poured brown in color.  A sweeter/maltier flavor than a traditional weiss, but just "ehh, whatever".

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a big white head that dissipates quickly.  Smells like burned malt with some skunkiness.  The taste is pretty lifeless with some maltiness.  I really felt this left something to be desired.

All around good beer. Has a dark velvety pour like a oatmeal or chocolate stout might. Has good thick head retention with vigorous CO2 activity. Taste is smooth and malty with hints of vanilla and chocolate. First ever Dunkel I’ve tried and definitely turned me onto the type and made me want to search out more.
Draft: pours a very dark brown with a small tan head.  Sweet and roasty aroma and a great sweet flavor with some roastiness.
Faint roasty aroma. Dark black in colour with off white head. Taste is sweet, almost dairy like, which nicely complements the roasty aroma. Creamy soft texture. Decent.

Dark ruby red/brown with a 1-finger tan head that quickly fades away leaving nothing. Nose is lightly sweet malts. Flavor is good, of roasted malt, with some but not too much bitterness, and some more malt at the end along with some hops. Mouth is pretty average.

Beer from a tap. Aroma of raisins, pretty fruity considering it’s called a dunkel. It was pretty dark, but I had just had a Newcastle and it was comparable in color, slightly darker. Tastes a bit light, fruity and raisin-tasting, not what I would expect from a dunkel but it was quite easy to drink and better than the swill they had on tap besides the Newcastle. If given the choice between this and any mainstream beer, I would go with this.
A sentimental beer meant to be drunk in large steins equaling large quantities.  A rich frothy head when served cool instead of cold.

Deep amber capped by small off white head. Nut in the nose. slight hazelnut and toffee with the first gulp. Decent balance.

Rated via BeerBuddy

Draft @ Yard House, Dedham, MA. Served in a pint. Minimal head or lace. Aromas of roasted nuts, caramel malt and a slight funk. Taste is lightly toasted malt, hint of coffee, and a touch of Euro hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is light, thin. Short abrupt finish. Not bad and is exactly as I thought it would be. I would skip this in a bottle but worth a try on draft, if you are in the mood for a dark lager.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with a medium sized creamy beige head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was vegetal malts, sour caramel and cherry. The flavor was sour caramel, cherry, red meat and a bit of wood. Medium finish and body. Totally forgettable.
Bottle - pours dark brown with next to no head. Has a malty flavor with a thin mouthfeel and a roasted aftertaste. Tastes like a lighter beer that is dark.

Bottle. Pours brown medium tan head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, bread. Taste is medium sweet malt. Medium-light body, thin texture. Sweet finish with a touch of bitter. Pretty quick finish. Easy drinking sweet flavor. Decent beer overall.
Good ale. Dunkel. Smooth brew. Brow with good lacing. Enjoyable fall or winter beer.

Bottle. Dark, clear brown with a very light head. that dissipates quickly. Earthy, yeasty aroma. Full, moderate roasted malt flavor with a nice tang on the tongue. Smooth finish with a slightly sweet aftertaste. Good beer.

Un aroma algo afrutado,que se percibe nada mas abrir la botella.Es una cerveza bastante filtrada,practicamente transparente,y muy palida.Tiene un sabor amargo bastante herbáceo,que se mantiene en el paladar durante 20 o 30 segundos.Tiene bastante gas,bastantes burbujas,y no mucha espuma ( fue servida en un vaso estandar ).No creo que sea una cerveza de de sesion,para degustar.La veo mas como un refresco o para tomar entre comidas.Yo la he comprado exportada,y el precio me ha parecido algo caro.Aun asi,es recomendable.
Poured into a wide mouth glass. This was a good dunkle but I’ve had better. Aroma was malty. Flavor was also sort of plain.

Pours a clear, medium brown with a 1 finger, fluffy beige head. Aroma is cereal grain, roasted nuts, has, a little grass and bready malt. Flavor is  cereal grain, heavier nutty notes than the aroma, bready malt, a little caramel and floral, spicy and grassy hops and a noticeable mineral note to the finish. Palate is light bodied, a little slick an entry, has a medium, sharp carbonation and off dry, finish. Not bad, though a little too grassy and over carbonated.
Malty, crisp, full.  In my opinion this is the dunkel by which all others should be judged.

Malty caramel aroma. Creamy one finger tan head that slims down film on top. A clear but deep caramel color.Roasted caramel taste with a hint of bitterness. Smooth mouth feel with a mild sweet finish. A real pleasure to drink.

Last beer I picked up. Nice light brown color yet not thick. Light passes through its to show a honey color. Very smooth and clean taste with a clean finish. At a mid price a case this beer maybe around a lot.
Sample at KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes clear dark brown with average white head.  Aroma of malt, bread and caramel.  Taste is sweet malt, caramel, hint of chocolate and a hint of hops.  Pretty good.

Clear dark copper, small off white head. Light caramel malty nose and taste, nutty and effervescent. Light caramel hop finish. Pretty basic. TLF (Totally Lagerboy Friendly) Not everything dark is nasty!
Pint tap at Jacoby’s in Detroit.  Poured a dark brown.  Lots of flavor, not still light, and a full smell with caramel.  It was perfect to wash down some bratwurst and potato pancakes.
Can from the LCBO. pours dark brown almost black with a very thin white head. aroma of malt and caramel. body is thin and oily. Pretty tasty and malty. rather smooth and light.

Bottle.  Pours a clear cola brown with a thin white head.  Light metallic notes, cool malt, toast and grain, soft caramel.  Medium bodied, sweet caramel, a light amount of bitter roast.  Thins out a touch as it heads to a light roast bitterness on the finish.  Decent enough, but not something I’d want to drink a lot of.

Draft in a pint glass - pours dark caramel with light beige head. Aroma is roasted malts.  Taste is sweet and a little bitter due to the roastiness. Light to medium body with light carbonation. Texture is oily and finishes a tad dry. Tastes more like a stout than a dunkel. Much betterthan the other warsteiner I’ve had.

Thick white head, nutty brown color, scent of toffee, toasted malt, coffee. Medium carbonization, taste of a bit sweet toasted malt with notes of coffee and caramel. Noticeable hop tase and aroma. Very good all in all.

Poured a medium head, dark copper color.  Aroma of caramel and syrup, some roasted malt.  Lite bitter,  lite sweettness.  Lighter bodied, slick texture. Ave carbonation.  Some roasted malt and caramel flavors with a bit of bitter bite.  But something is missing here.  Maybe its too thin.

330 ml bottle. Dark brown body with a diminishing small off-white head. Not much aroma, some caramel malt. Flavor is light malty, caramel and just a hint of roast. Not much bitter. Medium body. Nothing outstanding at all.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Not much really in the realm of aroma, just some malty sweetness. Kinda thin taste, and not any hop bitterness to speak of. Not awful, but not anything I would go out of my way to get.
At table and vine beer tasting, very dry and thin. Not characteristics I want in my dunkel. Also, under 5% abv, not a dunkel IMO. No finish.

I poured an 11.2oz bottle into an Oktoberfest mug.

Appearance: Pretty shade of chocolate brown with orange/red tones. Crystal-clear. Forms an average size beige sudsy/frothy head which retains and laces well.

Smell: Even though this is packaged in a brown bottle there is a definite skunkiness to the nose. Not nearly as bad as a Heineken, but a sourness that seems out of place for sure. A close inspection reveals a generic lager smell and hints of roasted malt and coffee.

Taste: Dark lagers are, in my mind, similar to black IPAs - they mess with your head because your eyes see something dark but your mouth tastes something light. Warsteiner Premium Dunkel definitely fits that bill - looks like a high-quality beer; smells like a green bottle macro pilsner, and tastes like a standard German lager but with more refinement.

The entire first half and even most of the finish consists of a mild, familiar palate. It’s that taste of lagers that conform to the Bavarian Purity Law but don’t have anything substantial or original to them. A light cereal, milled grained taste and mild bitterness. Just as it finishes all the flavor rushes in at once. It’s a pleasant taste of iced coffee, dark chocolate and generic lager all at once. These flavors combine for a simultaneously bitter and sweet palate, yet quite mild overall. The skunked aroma is apparent in the palate - bringing down what should be a good or even excellent beer to one that’s just plain okay.

Mouthfeel: On the lighter end of medium bodied. Thicker than your average lager and not quite as fizzy, although carbonation is noticeable. 

Drinkability: Though technically a lager, Warsteiner Premium Dunkel doesn’t drink like your average macro lager. Much smoother with a palate of genuine flavor. The sourness in the nose and aftertaste take some time to tolerate, though. The 4.8% ABV is totally accurate and this would make a great session beer if you could get it on tap or in cans.

Overall, I wanted to like and rate Warsteiner Premium Dunkel a little higher than I am, because it is a tasty, drinkable beer - but with flaws that are a little distracting.
Bottle. Malty/caramel aroma. Similar taste, pretty bland and some watery texture. Not bad, not good.  Won’t grab again. 4.9% alcohol.
Very nice for a style I’m not crazy about. The pour was dark brown with an off white head. Very malty aroma, sweet and inviting. The flavor is malty sweet but not too sweet. It has a nice balance.
Aroma of chocolate malts and some apple. Appearance is dark red/brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is bubbly. Decent Dunkel.

Warsteiner Premium Dunkel has a medium, beige head and a clear, dark brown (reddish under light) appearance, with lots of fine bubbles streaming up. The aroma is mild and is of toasted barley and coffee. Taste is of rather lightly toasted barley malt, some coffee, and a touch of hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is mostly light, but some body is present with this one. Warsteiner Premium Dunkel finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, and semi-dry. Overall, this is a very good dark lager, and I think it’s worth a try.  RJT

Aroma: Typical beer aroma. When I think beer, this is the smell that comes to mind. Not cool, I know. Faint smell of roasted malt, faint citrus...not much.

Appearance: Dark, transparent brown with a dense off-white head which has no longevity. 

Taste: Not as bad as I would’ve thought. Roasted malts are present, a little citrus, a little sweetness, some funk. Some chocolate undertones which is kinda cool.

Palate: Smooth and crisp, light bodied for a darker beer. Best part is it’s in balance.

Overall: There’s nothing really bad about this beer, in fact it’s quite drinkable and better than most of the macro shit out there, but it is kinda boring. I was expecting a lot worse however and was pleasantly surprised.
On tap at Biergarten Albany.  Pours a deep brown with a nice big tan head.  Taste is big on roasted malts, pretty sweet.  Goes down very easy, medium thickness, tastes pretty good, solid beer.
Bottle.  Toasty malt nose.  Pours cola colored with thin off-white head. Taste is mild toasted barley, chocolate with mild hops.  Thin mouthfeel, but sessionable
At Edelweiss on Irving Park. Nice slightly roasted malty dunkel. A little thin bodied thought. Cola colored. Serving: Tap
Aroma is sweet chocolate malt with a little roastiness. Taste is a nice toasted chocolate malt with minimal bitterness.
Pours a deep ruby body with a thin white head. Flavor is lightly roasted with caramel and chocolate. Very thin.
Bottle. Have had much better dunkels. Taste was roasted but too watery, Aroma was just slightly too skunky. Nice brown color, some head. Just middle of the road.
Dark n tasty.  I was happy to have the maltyness of the beer with a bit of lager taste.  Great beer to drink, not to heavy, good on the taste buds too.
Bottle: Pours fairly dark with a medium foamy head.  Thin malty aroma. Malt flavor.  Not bad.
Can. caramel malt (or something like that) hits the nose a little, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, lively, a little bitter finish. Almoust no head

A good tasting, mild German style Dunkel.  True to form, not a heavy dark beer, but more of a lighter dark beer.  Right on style for this beer.  I haven’t had this beer in awhile, I forgot how good tasting this brew was….I had more than one!

(Canette de 500 ml)  Le liquide a une robe brune pâle.  Un anneau de mousse flotte sans conviction.  Le nez est fait de grains rôtis : on peut percevoir des arômes de café et des parfums chocolatés.  Le goût est peu éloigné avec des flaveurs légèrement rôties qui permettent l’éclosion de saveurs qui rappellent les noix grillées.  En bouche, le liquide est bien peu étoffé avec un pétillement assez fort et une texture plutôt légère.  La finale est amère et métallique.  Ordinaire.
12oz bottle.  Malt, cereal, caramel and tobacco in aroma.  Taste is sweet bready malt and caramel with light spice hops in background.  Thin-ish palate.  Kinda plain and lifeless overall.
500ml can. Deep brown colour with ample head. Carmel and toasted grains. Overall I rather liked it.

Schwach getreidiger Geruch. Der Antrunk des Bieres ist mild getreidig und kaum malzig. Zum Mittelteil wird das Bier würziger, bleibt insgesamt aber mild. Auch etwas malziger wird das Bier hier, wirklich malzig ist es aber erst im Nachgeschmack, wenn auch nicht wirklich lange. Zudem kommt eine hopfig-bittere Note auf, die den Nachgeschmack positiv auffrischt. Insgesamt ein mildes Dunkel, bei dem der Nachgeschmack das "Glanzstück" darstellt. 	 
Test vom 22.7.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 7,8,9,11,10,9 - 9,00

Aroma: Bready malts with hints of doughiness.
Appearance: Clear dark amber, almost brown, with a rocky, white head.
Taste: Medium sweetness backed by a light sourness.
Palate: Light body, thin texture, average carbonation, long, sour finish.
Overall: Meh...it’s drinkable, but it’s so thin and flavorless that I’m not sure it’s worth drinking. It’s a cheap, dark lager to give to folks who like Budweiser and the like but want something different and imported. I’m just not impressed.

(11.2oz bottle from AJ’s Arcadia).  Pours clear dark brown with red hue and tan head.  Average carbonation.  Aroma has lots of sweet caramel malts, biscuit and bubblegum.  Taste follows suit with sweet caramel and biscuity notes.  Very crisp beer.  Light bodied with a slick texture.  Smooth finish.  Easy to drink.

11.2oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours deep brown with a very light beige head.  Aroma of nuts, bread, and light hops.  Some banana notes in the flavor too.  Average texture.  A decent beer, but nothing special.

330 mL bottle. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. The aroma is coffee, pale malts, and lager yeast. The flavor is mellow and bittersweet. The palate is medium with a smooth bitter finish. Overall, a pleasant beer.

A: The pour is sort of a cola brown color with a finger of off-white head.

S: Smells of burnt grain and burnt toast with some mild coffee aromas.  There is a fairly strong amount of roasted malt and a mild nuttiness.  Some caramel and toffee sweetness, but it’s overwhelmed.

T: Starts off with a strong roasted malt and burnt toast flavor.  Hints of coffee with a walnut-like nuttiness.  Lightly sweet with some toffee and molasses, but there is a hint of acidity.

M: Fairly light in body with a medium level of carbonation.

O: Wasn’t a fan of this one.  Too much emphasis on the roast and it was a bit too much for such a light beer.

Not a bad dunkel.  It has a lot more body and flavor than some other dunkels I’ve tasted, but it’s certainly not the best.  It’s definitely in the ’average’ of dunkels in my opinion.  This beer pours a dark brown color with an adequate off-white head with minimal lacing.  The body is a little thin and watery, but has some malty and brown sugar flavor.  Some hops, earth and light chocolate malt also show through.

Good ole’ Warsteiner Dunkel, the beer I used to think was the "expensive" stuff of my youth.  Guess what?  This stuff is still drinkable.  Malt is the featured ingredient here.  Tad thin, inoffensive, drinkable.
12 oz bottle, aroma is good but not great. Taste was surprisingly good compared to Warsteiner’s Verum. Not a bad dunkel at all, really drinkable. A good winter beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark chestnut brown with minimal head. Aroma of red wine, chocolate malt, fig, and walnut. Flavor comes off as a mix of roasted malt and Fig Newtons. Thin mouthfeel with chocolate and dark fruit in the finish. The fig-chocolate mix was odd but intriguing. I will check out some similar beers.

Not quite a slam dunkel but delicious, nonetheless.  Pours clear mahogany brown, with two inch off white head, very little lace.  Taste is somewhat bland, however well balanced and nice malty finish.  Definitely something I would drink again.  Wouldn’t be a bad choice for those used to the macro brews.
Bottle.  Pours a dark bruin body with an off white head.  A malty body a bit thin and grain with notes of sweet toast, hints of oats, and a bit grain y and slightly sweet.  Eh not so good.
Light, drinkable, with a slight dark fruit flavor and some roastiness, it is a great session beer.
A suprisingly light drinking dunkel. Pours pretty standard, dark coffee-like body with a thin creamy head. Light aroma and a crisp taste that doesn’t linger too long. I liked it.

Originally rated January 2009. This German Dunkel pours a dark copper colour with a frothy off-white head, decent retention and lacing. Tiny bubbles compose the carbonation factor. Malty nose on the mild side with a watery and slightly creamy mouthfeel. Fruity taste, with a corn aftertaste. Not really a complex brew, being a refreshing swill that is on the darker side of things.

Appearance:  mahogany brown, with lovely dark red highlights.  Aroma:  toasted cinnamon raisin bread, caramel, charred chestnuts.  Flavor:  sweet and malty, with flavors of honey roasted peanuts, caramel, toffee, molasses, root beer, and a little copper.  Finish:  surprisingly crisp for how sweet the flavors were, with a pleasant carbonated tingle giving way to smoothness.  Notes:  Very nice.  I like a sweeter beer.  This was sweet without being as rich as a doppelbock, and had a nice balanced palate.
Pours a deep amber with a dark red hue, small white head.  Deep woodsy, caramel aroma.  Very sweet, slightly sour.  Palate is dry, medium bodied creamy texture.

Poured a clear brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is skunky with bread.  Some caramel as well.  Taste is smooth but a bit watery.  Some interesting caramel flavors with bread.  The finish is a little strange with some earthy notes.  Overall very refreshing.

Pours a dark chestnut brown with a thin, creamy off-white head. The aroma is pleasant but understated with a faint grainy sweetness. The taste is much more pronounced, with a dominant malt base that features flavors of cereal grains, cherry sweetness, and maybe even a bit of weak coffee and raisins. Although certainly crisp and clean, the prickly, fine carbonation is almost distracting. Overall, this is a solid, crisp, drinkable beer. It isn’t remarkable in any sense, but it is very nice.

Bottle.  Pours clear, very dark orange and red, with a small creamy beige head.  Aromas of caramel and red berry, and slightly sour cherry.  The flavor is sweet raisin and toffee, light grass, and tart fruit pits; plenty of fruity malt.  Medium carbonation, smooth, and a touch tart.  Good.  [602]
Redish brown in color, smaller head, sweet roasty aroma and taste. Not a bad beer.

Dark red in colour with a small white head. Light malty aroma. Lightly sweet and roasty in taste with a nice soft bitter aftertaste. Overall not a bad dunkel. Worth another go if the opportunity arises.
Very much like the pilsner just a little thicker but still very inoffensive and not that bad of a dunkel.

12 oz. bottle served in lager glass- poured a transparent very slightly faded brown, light carbonation, wafer thin head formed but didn’t lace at all.  Faint aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, and Euro-hops.  Hits the mouth with a light but pleasant body, malt was sweetened that extends into the middle, finish has some milding hops to it.  Another one I used to drink by the pitcher when back in MI... where the hell is all this nostalgia coming from lately?

pours clear pale brown with an ok-head. bread crust, cereals, grainy, caramel malts but no toffee-like notes. little roastiness. very light body, watery, strong carbonation. not horrible but it’s still better than many big imports.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a clear medium brown with medium off-white head.  Really smooth, medium body, medium lacing, medium lacing.  Taste is slightly sweet light nut.  I would have this again.
Overall not bad. Dark black in color little carbonation. Mild black licorice taste. Malty aroma.

My fourth beer of Christmas 2010.  The dunkel poured a dark tea color.  No head at pouring.  This is a sweet light body dark lager.  I have not had many dark lagers to compare.  The finish was clean and smooth. This is just not a complex beer.  On a 3M trip we visited Minneapolis and attended an Octoberfest in one of the neighborhoods.  The dunkel was served in the large beer glasses.  The music was fun and the beer good.

Pours dark brown. Aroma is a little funky-barnyard and basement aromas. Medium-bodied palate is creamy with some wheat on the back palate/finish. A little roasted nut and coffee on the palate as well. Good, not great.
Pours dark brown with little head that retains. This beer would be good after smashing some bottles I think.
tastes like a normal dunkel, this beer is ok. its pretty smooth. prob wouldnt buy one again
On tap at the Golden Kiwi.  Pours dark reddy brown. Very little head.   Fairly thin body. Nice slightly nutty, malty aroma and taste.  Pretty good!
Not bad at all for a Dunkel. Pours dark brown but not to heavy or thick. Sweet with fruit and malt but refreshing with just the right amount of bitterness. Liked this one.
pours like tea with a white head that faded quickly smelled like vegetables and grass tasted sweet wuth a seet aftertaste ok but nothing great

Clear deep "tea" color with some light orange highlights.  Slightly off white head that was not very remarkable.  Not much retention either.  Fair amount of roasted malt in the fragrance.  A scent of toasted grain and roasted coffee bean.  I can’t really detect much else.  There is something else, but not sure what it is.  Maybe it’s a faint butter.  Not unpleasant and balanced well.  Flavor was of the toasted grain.  The coffee taste was present, but not out front.  Getting an almost walnut like character in the taste.  Medium mouthfeel.  Left a little to be desired as far as the coating of the throat and tongue.  Did a fair job though.  It was a bit dry and it went down comfortably.  Smooth.  This brew is not bad.  I didn’t find anything real complicated about it.  Nice session brew.  Would pair well with a cool evening.  If this beer were available at a social event, I would drink it without fuss.
Bottled. Dark brown color with light brown head. Sweet malty aroma with roasted bread hints. Taste, sweet, caramel with roasted grain and nuts. Nice Dunkel.

On tap at the Bavarian Brathaus in Cary NC. It poured a mahogany brown with a thin head. The aroma was very sweet malt, fruity notes and some hints of honey. Flavor was much the same...the body was a bit thinner than expected with a clean, easy finish.  Not bad.

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a thick beige head - good retention. Aroma was malty and lightly ferrous. Flavor was similar to aroma - malty, sightly metallic with an almost imperceptible hop finish - almost not worth mentioning. Thin watery palate.
Had on draught up in Helen, GA for Oktoberfest. Nice dark brown color with caramel color head, nice smooth aroma and taste. Had a sort of sweet licorice taste with a hint of hops.
Light and clean with some caramel roastyness, nuts and bananas.  Simple beer with just enough flavor to keep you interested.  Smooth, slightly roasty finish.
Pours brown with tiny head off draft.  Aroma is caramel, nuts and a little roastyness. Taste is sweet with the caramel coming through.  Very smooth.

Dark brown pour into thick tan head that dissipates into sticky lacing that melts into a pool of foam. Aroma of roasted malt, sweet chocolate, toasty yeasty biscuit. Initial flavor of sweet toasted malt, nuts, and caramel that fades into bitter chocolate with a slight hint of hops in the finish.

Aroma is of weak coffee with a bit of dark-roasteded malt, some faint noble hops, and a hint of soy sauce.



Taste is like coffee flavored candy or soda, but not overly sweet. This beer clearly is made with a small percentage of highly-roasted malt rather than a large percentage of medium-roasted malt, giving it some schwarzbier character. It has low minerality and bitterness, making for a somewhat sweet overall balance.



Palate is medium-bodied with high carbonation.
One of the better brews from Warsteiner, a good autumn brew with a light body.

12 oz. bottle
Ebony brown with a thin light head that quickly settles.
A floral, fruit like, almost wine like taste.
What a nice aroma.
tap at Bohemian hall beer garden - not bad... yeasty and grassy. smooth and roasty with hints of chocolate. quaffable.

Has a very dark brown color with an orange tint, light ivory head.  Smelled like stale cheese pizza and mushrooms. This may well have been the lightest dark beer or German beer I ever had, and I don’t mean that in any flattering way. It tasted like basement aroma, dust, and stale malts. Drain pour!

500ml can. Pours a very rum n’ coke colour with a tight tan head that leaves a nice little lace. A little nutty on the nose with a fair wheat presence and a hint of underlying fruit. A typical lageresque entry with some mildly dark notes that are hard to identify and very lax in the finish. Mostly unimpressive.

"Oh, how I wish I could speak the German language!" A previous reviewer wrote this. Really, after a few pints of this, you will be able to speak fluenbt Deutsch (more or less). Had several pints on tap here in Houston on this hot August afternoon - it all went down very smooth. Great color and a balanced taste of caramel and nuts, yet you can taste the hops. I think this beer is "situational." Tastged great and we were in the mood for it.

Clear, dark brown in color with a creamy khaki colored head. Grainy, toasted malt aroma and a similar flavor. Palate was on the thin side, but that seemed to be the intent. I can picture many Germans pounding a few of these in the evening.
Warsteiner von Warstein. Oh, how I wish I could speak the German language!
Dark amber or brown.  Eggshell head that’s thick.  Aroma of slightly roasted malt with a crisp, clean taste of dark toast with a tinge of bitterness.  Quite nice.

Bottle.  Pours dark mahogany with a thin tan head.  Aroma and flavor of sweet caramel malt, some chocolate, a touch of fruit, very little hoppiness.  Palate is on the thin side.  Nice, unchallenging dunkel.

Pours black (dark amber under light) with a thin tan head. The aroma is very grainy and roasty. The taste is grainy with nice savoury roast overtones. The lager yeast gives it a light, flora aroma reminiscent of pale lagers. Likewise, it has a thin, lagerlike palate and aftertaste. Good, but not great

330 ml bottle.  Pours brown with an average off-white head.  Aroma of grassy, piney hops and some toasted malt.  Medium, crisp body.  Taste is light, grassy hops, buckwheat, hints of honey, toasted malt and alcohol.  Medium, slightly hoppy finish.  I’m not impressed by this brew.

Bottle from my neighbor on the 4th. This was given to her and she hates it. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma of bready german malts. Light bodied but not watery and very clean on the palate. Dark bready malt backbone with average attenuation, with just enough spicy hops to balance it out and keep the bitterness barely detectable. Not all that bad, but certainly not exciting. Good for pairing with grilled foods.
Very weak, pale flavor. What flavor is there does not last long. What was there seemed ok but not great.

Poured from bottle. Very winey nose; reminded me of an inexpensive Pinot Noir with a certain lacing of grain -- there’s also a touch of sulfur on the nose that blew off quickly. Pours a light brown with a pillowy head. The flavor is light roast -- not really overwhelming or even strong, just a little more roasty than a lager. Not much hops to it, and it seemed weak and watery. Average at best.
On tap, pours dark brown with a beige head. caramel malts, bread and sweet fruits dominate this one. Not bad.
12 ounce bottle purchased at local Winn Dixie supermarket for $1.00ea in 12-pack. Good.
Mahogany colour with a frothy head. Good aroma of malt with brown sugar fruit and raisin. Nice malt flavour. Good bitter texture. well balanced. Nothing special.
Pours dark amber with a quickly fading beige head. Aroma of apple, pear, caramel, honey, bready malt. Taste has lots of roasty malts and fruity sweetness. Medium light body, soft carbonation.

Bottle at restaurant.  Dark brown with small beige head.  Aroma slight with roasted malts.  Taste dark malts, caramel.  Mouth feel thin.  Tiny hop on the finish.

Really much less than it’s color would suggest
Clear coffee-color, beige foamy head, some lacing.  Notes of expresso and chocolate.  Taste reflects aroma with just a trace of bitterness.  Smooth and well-balanced.

Dark, but with a clear lightish brown color. Very little head, and a mild amount of carbonation. 

A very pungent, alcohol-heavy sour smell. Very strong. 

High, heavy alcohol flavor. Heavy acidity. A dark, sour malt flavor. Lots of toffee and caramel on the back end.

Incredibly thick and heavy aftertaste that sits on the tongue for a while. This is one you may have to choke down. Considering how dark it is, it is relatively smooth, but not one where you can knock back 3-4 of them. Better when fresher.
Very light dunkel. Nose and taste of caramel malts, molasses and roasted earth. Rated 3/27/03
Copper brown pour with white head. Scent is all malt. Taste is malts. This is weak compared to some others.

Dark color with off white head. Very little aroma. It is pretty smooth overall. It may be a little sweet and lacking some balance. Very malty with very little hop presence. Mild dry and buttery finish. Its decent. Not much to choose from on tap in a dry county.

Dark pour with tan head, this one was out of a two liter boot.  Chosen for it’s taste and drinkability, it was a perfect mix between the two.  That said, not a lot of tastes there, but a solid brew overall.

12oz bottle from bevmo.  Pours dark brown with a frothy tan head that quickly dissappears. Really looks like a glass of cola. Aroma of caramel and roasted malts. Rather thin body almost watery. Sligtly biitter finish. Drinkable but not exceptional.
Pours a dark brown with a short white head. Smooth taste. Aroma is roasty and nutty. Taste is of water and dough.
Dark brown with orange/red tones and minimal head. Smells of malt, and grapefruity hops. Taste is bitter, favoring malt.

can 4.8%.  Poured transparent auburn with a thinning beige head. The aroma is nutty but faint.  Lighter mouthfeel with some prickly carbonation.  Flavour of roasted malt and toffee. Medium bitter finish and very easy drinking.
A reddish-brown beer with basically no head. The aroma is kind of grainy and not good at all. The taste is grainy, skunky. Blah
Bottled. Brown with thicker white head. Aroma is malty caramel and citrus hop light Malty taste; a little roasty. Very lightly bitter lingering
12 ounce bottle A dark brown pour off white head .taste smooth with hints of caramel, nuts, A good beer

Draught.  Pours mahogany brown with minimal head.  Aromas of malts, roasted nuts and herbs.  Taste of sweet caramels and malts with a weak bitter finish.  Overall it was just average, nothing really wrong with it but it didn’t wow either.

Extremely dissapointed with this one. A dark amber brew with a slight white head. Smell is a bit roasted, pleasant. The taste is just too bland, bitter hops taste, minimal chocolate notes. Not getting this one again.

On tap at Tap Exchange.  Dark brown body topped with a small, quickly receding head.  Nose is malty, roasty and a bit of biscuit.  Flavors of lightly sweet, bit of coffee, toffee and roasty.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.
Pours a clear mahogany with a minimal off-white head.  Aroma is lager yeast and wet dog.  Flavor is the same only stronger, sweet malt and toffee.  Low carbonation.

Pours a deep, clear, reddish-brown with a good sized bubbly head that evaporates in seconds.  Surprisingly light and a little citrusy.  Unfortunately the dominant aroma i get is unpleasantly metallic.  Light on flavour but at least there’s nothing offensive there.  Very short finish.

It tastes like a dunkel, but is frankly rather bland.
Pours a cloudy brown with a non-existent white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt. Flavor is pretty sweet but also really thin. Not great.
Tasted this one some years ago at a train to Germany. Was very drinkeable, but I need to re-taste to get proper points for this beer.

From bottle. Medium malt sweetnes, fairly clean, but with some light metallic tang, carbonic gaseousness, and beany hops. Dark ruby-brown clear with thin light tan foamy lacing head. Medium watery body with medium-high carbonation. Starts with medium malt sweetness, caramel, and some nutty character. Carbonic acidity with medium bitterness in the finish. Light bitter chalky after and a bit of sweetness. Mild oxidation notes, too.

500ml can.  Pours a clear, dark reddish brown, with a decent beige head that quickly diminished.  Has very little aroma, what is there is malt, faint strawberry jam, and almost a faint smell of rubber band?  The taste is slightly sweet, dark malt notes, again the berry notes.  Mild citrus, and caramel in the bitter finish.  A light bodied, easy drinking dark beer.

Very malty aroma. It poured a dark brown color with minimal head retention. The taste was superb and had notes of bread, caramel, and toasted nuts. Smooth on the way down. This is a great dunkel that I have been enjoying for years now.
A classic German with just the right amount of syrupiness on the nose and in the palate, a nice grains taste, and a smooth finish. Could do with more head though.
Dark amber/brown ruby hue off white creamy head sweet caramel malt aroma and taste of sweet caramel, nut and roasted malts ... good chillin medium bodied dunkel
Bottle via coldbrewky. Pours a dark amber with a good size white head. Notes of caramel dominate the nose while some nutty toffee flavor shines through the taste. Nice light, lively body.

Bottle via the rip and run.  Pours a light clear brown.  Crisp with light caramel and nut tone.  Head dissipates quickly and is left to a central lily pad complex  from carbonation alone.  Body is sweet and light.  Toffee and caramel mostly not much in the grain/cereal department.  A refreshing quaffer.  Sweet finish.

Warsteiner Brauerei Haus Original Brauerei-Abfullung, Cramer D-59564 Warstein / Germany--Warsteiner Dunkel--Premium Dunkel--Eine Konigin Unter Den Bieren.  2009 Release.  11.2 oz. Bottle.  4.80% ABV--20 IBU’s Est.?  3.65 / 5.0.  Foamy thin mild lace light tan head.  lear bright dark deep ruby red black color.  Mild hop light toasted mild dark fruit aroma.
