12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours amber with a average fizzy white head, which lasts for most of the beer but leaves no lacing.  The aroma is light with slight caramel notes.  The flavor is of light molasses and of caramel.  There is also a very slight hint of oak and slight butterscotch.  The body is light to medium with a watery texture and lively carbonation.

Pours a reddish brown with a 1 finger head that forms extremely quickly and falls almost just as fast. The nose almost is like mild cedar. The taste is too quick though and doesn’t linger at all, leaving barely anything for you to remember it by. Everything leading up to that was promising, but the flavor to me is a let down.

Pours a clear dark reddish-brown with a rapidly diminishing head.  Aroma is muted with only a faint maltiness and typical DMS.  Taste is clean and suprisingly light with a mild roasty character.  Finishes just as clean.  Well, it’s better than their other lager.

330ML oz bottle via Roth’s. Pours a clear  DARK REDDISH BROWN WITH A LARGE BEIGE HEAD that quickly recedes to nothing...talking about going limp quick..it is the minutemen of beer here.  Nose is malty with some toasted grains. Taste starts with some semi-sweet caramel, then some toasted graininess, a little chocolate, some mild hops, and a semi-sweet finish. Body is light/medium. Carbonation is medium. A non-offensive non-memorable backyard beer.
Clear brown color topped by a low creamy head.  Nutty taste. Surprisingly refreshing light medium body. Better as it warms.

Bottle.  Light grain and dark malt with some nuttiness in the nose.  Pours amber with a brownish tinge and a soapy, fizzly tanned head.  Sweetish taste with nuttiness, light chocolate and a good dose of caramel - a lot like a candy bar.  Faint sourness doesn’t serve this well but does match the light graininess, and the overall blend is fine.  Touch of herb.  Pleasant/lightly crisp mf.  Medium-full, malty body and a good enough reason to break out the Warsteiner glass. :)  Really, a decent mass-produced, I wouldn’t turn down another.
Pretty good. A little too sweet though. Lightly roasted all malt profile. Low carbonation and very drinkable. It does not have much of an aroma.

Bottle. The aroma is sweet and toasted malt, black color with a thin beige head, flavor is good like toasted malt and some caramel or something else sweety, little too bitter.
Cerveja preta, com aroma de malt torrado e doce, espuma bege e fina, sabor doce tipo caramelo, pouco amarga.

This beer pours a cola color with a light head that didn’t last long.  Aroma is thin but has both malt and hops.  Mouth feel is thin but clean.  The beer itself is pretty straight forward.  It is mostly malty with some nuttiness and hop undertones.  Like so many macro brewed beers this one seems to be more concerned with having no negative aspects than it is with having positives.

The aroma was nutty and lightly spicy from hops with a light chocolate characteristic and a clean nose. Malt was most prevalent, like a light milk chocolate. The beer poured into the glass crystal clear amber brown with a lasting tight bubble nearly white head which laced the glass. The flavor began on the palate malty and nutty and quickly dried to light chocolate and a very light spicy hop flavor. The flavor was toasty and nicely bittered to offset the malt. The finish was dry with just light lasting impressions of the malts and bittering hops into the aftertaste. The body was medium and the carbonation was moderate. A nice dunkel, very easy to consume, could use more malt, but still a solid brew! 12 ounce bottle.

Nutty and malty aroma is quite sweet.  Clear chestnut brown coloured body is topped by a low cream coloured head that recedes rapidly to a thin partial cover and ring.  Nutty and sweet malts with light bitterness.  Never cloying or sticky but tasty and refreshing.  Light medium body with strong effervescence that stimulates the tip of the tongue.  Tulip glass.  Allowed to warm from fridge temperature.  Bottle (BCLS at 39th and Cambie, Apr-07).
A standard dunkel, which is a fine choice any day of the week by me.  No hops, Nice, sweet and malty.  Had in bottle in Columbus.

Hardly noticeable sweet aroma. Decent appearance with very little head retention. Average flavor with nice maltiness and mild bitter finish. Some chocolate notes. The palate is smooth and pleasant. All in all a good beer.
$5.25/sixer. cheaper than giant american brews and better.  metallic malty nose. light malty flavor and very refreshing...
Good German Brew. Pours darkish brown with a hint of red. Taste good would buy again
Bottle.  Pours a clear brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is on the yeasty/bready side, with some malt tones.  Flavor is much the same.  A bit on the thin side, but rather drinkable.
12oz Btl. Pours a toasty deep cherry red with a light tan head, smells of sweet malts, caramel is present in the nose, nutty toffy flavor with a medium to thick mouthfeel. Very pleasent beer
12oz bottle.  Filtered and dark ruby brown.  Off-white ring of head.  Malty bready nose with a touch of toffee.  Light to medium bodied.  Easy body and nice smooth malt flavor.  Crisp.

Bottle.  ..	malty, carmelley, somewhat metallic. .. 	Dark brown, clear - cola like.  Witish head. ..	malty with metallic notes. .. 	Medium body, light carbonation. .. .	good german dunkel, but a little thin.
I enjoy this in a stein, freshly poured from tap with pretzels, a very nice session beer
Great burnt taste, lively on the tongue...very refreshing.  Nice dark color, head diminishes quickly.

This is a fairly smooth beer and goes down very easy. The flavor is not that complex at all. This beer is like drinking a really great Bud light with out the fizz. There is a corn and grainy taste  to it which probally gives it that non fizzy taste but overall it is an awesome beer to funnel or bring to partys and play pong with.
Nice bready and burnt malts that Finishes clean and dry. Light to medium-bodied with smooth, slightly fizzy carbonation. Enjoyable.
Pours a dark caramel color with little head.  Bread and hops comprise the aroma.  Taste is bread and fruit with some hops at the end.  Light bodied.  Nice beer!

Pours a dark purple-brown with a moderate head which dissipates quickly. Lager-yeast and hop aroma, dark and fruity. Unmalted grain taste - grain-like and unrefined. Bready yeast, malt-beverage aftertaste. Low on carbonation, creamy body but thin. Overall a cheap half-complete beer.

Clear mahogany pour, with a red hue, the tan head was medium sized and bubble.  Aroma is light, mostly sweet malts.  The flavor is true to the aroma.  There are hints of citrus and grass in the flavor.  The Beer is light to medium bodied.  Slower clean finish.  I pretty enjoyable beer.

12oz. Bottle

Warsteiner Dunkel poured a super clear dark mahogany. Dark ruby hues. A 1+ finger bubbly off-white head that quickly fell to just a little wisp along the top.

The smell is good. I pick up dark fruits, some cherry. Along with some sweet bready malt. Smells pretty tasty.

The taste isn’t as good as the smell. It’s doughy and slightly sweet up front. Then it’s all roasted and burnt malts which quickly turns to bitterness. I’m assuming from the burnt malts. 

Mouthfeel is average. It’s a little slick as it goes down the throat. Pretty watery though. Definately not it’s best point.

The drinkability is just above average. It’s an easy drinker. 

Sampled 10/3/06

Pours a dark copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is of slight roasted malts, and dark fruits.  Not a very strong or complex aroma.  Flavor is light of dark fruits, with a slight roastiness at the end.  There was a little more from the flavor then what I was expecting.  It’s an ok brew but nothing great.

Bottle: Dark amber body with plenty of tan head and some lacing.  Malty aroma with metalic and faint floral notes.  Enters creamy, with building roasted chocoalte notes.  Some faint citrus notes mix in till a simple dry finish that just dies at the end.  Good body with a fitting level of cabonation.  Better than expected.
Eh, Not a big fan of this Dunkel.  Palate and flavor doesnt seem to match the aroma and look to me.
slightly better than the original. darker and tastier. the smoky aroma hints at more flavor than it really has.

dark brown, very clear. looks just like coke.
almost no head.
malty in flavor
not much hops.
chocolatey.
a little smoky

overall not too bad, but not really good, although i admit this is not at all my style.

Draught @ West 50, Mississauga, ON: Brown in colour, much more transparent and light in colour than I’d expected.  A thin head that soon disappeared.  The aroma was pleasing, quite a bit of roasted malt, some black licorice.  The taste was surprisingly subdued, almost bland, very watery.  Elements of those roasted malts and licorice, but all hidden away.  Disappointing, I had high expectations.

A dark clear brown.  Not much to the aroma, but I suppose a bit of roast flavor.  Not much to the taste either, but a hint of maltiness and suprisingly light.  I could drink this all night, but it really doesn’t have much to it in the way of flavor or body.  Nothing special.
Dark, clear brown.  Nose is slightly malty with rye bread whiffs.  Flavour is roasty with some bread and caramel.  Finishes a tad sticky.  Nice simply easy drinker.
Bottle; Nose of roasted malts with some vanilla notes;Cherry-walnut colored with a medium glass-lacing head; flavor is caramel, roasty malt with a small smole note.

As Borat would say NICE!

Great on the palate... Good taste and goes down too easy.  Keep the beer flowing!
Very dark pour with very little head.  Initial taste was warm with a little bit of sweet malt coming through, followed by a nice bitter crisp

This beer is commonly available in the US, but I thought it a fairly good example of a dunkel weiss, given a fairly limited amount of experience with the style.

Pours a copper-colored body with a good amount of what I’ll call "mainstream beer" head on it, which fades fairly quickly.

Aroma is faint, but is slightly sweet and a bit spicy (maybe cinammon?).

Taste is caramel malt, a touch of souriness, and a bit of oakiness.  In my memory, this is fairly typical for the dunkel style.

Mouthfeel is not thin, but is not overpoweringly sticky.  I found this beer fairly drinkable, and on those times when I want something very malty (I should add, in the interest of full disclosure, that I’m usually looking for something hoppy), I would not rule this out.
Brown color with a light tan head that doesn’t last long. Good malty aroma and taste.
From the bottle, pours a medium brown color with a quickly fading head.  Aroma and taste of roasted malts.  Kind of reminds me of Michelob Amber Bock.

On draft at lunch today. Appearance is the best part of this brew - a lovely black that lets very little light through, capped by an inch of off-white head. Aroma is nuts and alcohol. Has a good feeling in the mouth, but the flavor lacks punch. You get caramel, nuts, and smoke. Not bad, but everything comes on too weak, and there aren’t enough layers "coming on" to begin with. Disappointing.
Pours in nicely.  Caramel color with a medium head.  No distinctive taste, except for the few hops at the end.  Nothing different, and liked other Dunkels over this one.

The description "A light bodied clean dark lager" is very fitting.  It pours dark with a carbonated looking light tan head.  Aroma is hard to detect due to the smell of alcohol and  carbonation. The taste is simple; malt, molasses, and caramel.  The taste of alcohol and carbonation are too apparent to really enjoy the other flavors.

Pours like a coca cola w/ smaller head.  Looks like cola as well, maybe a little darker.  Nice aroma, not overwhelming.  Tad bitter in the back of my mouth but doesn’t last.  Kind of thin feel on the tongue.  I am on tail end of cold so perhaps this rating isn’t fair.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear cola color with a faint patch of light tan bubbles.  Aroma is of rich malts, raisins, plums, biscuits, molasses and caramel with notes of citrus and smoke.  Smooth, light bodied and moderately carbonated.  Ending is malty sweet.
Pretty good beer.  Not overwhelming with flavor, but does provide a smooth taste.  Bottle.
Ordinary - no pizzazz for this kind of beer.  Cosmetically pleasing [look, smell, pour etc] but no real definintve characteristics.  Try one or two, then move on

A dark brown/red pour with an off white head that fades quickly. An aroma of a light chocolate lagerish thing. A flavor of light chocolate with a tad of an off not really bitter but just odd. Not a lot of flavor. A tad thin not a beer that is just barely good.
Mahogany color without much head. Medium consistancy. Had this beer with some pizza, with which it went well.

Pour is a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is hard to find.  Flavor pretty much the same.  Nothing really here and so not a dunkel.  Just one of these beers to fill out your make a six pack and not really worth the time.

i was looking forward to finally trying this.....pours a dark brown colour, exact colour of the bottle, not alot of aroma but hints of cocoa. the taste is spectacular! nicely bittered! very smooth and great aftertaste! a winner in my book.

Bottle - November 2006 - Thanks to GHawener. Pours a deep copper color with a nice, creamy beige head. Aroma is very slight caramel, malty. Taste is very toffee like, caramelly, almost like a scottish ale. Medium body, short aftertaste. Nice and warming.
Not much to smell here.  Thin body and light flavor make it easy to drink.  Not much malt character compared to other dunkels, though.  Meh.
Great beer.  A nice dark beer with a good mouthful.  Creamy and smells of roasted malts.  Very rich and a solid brew. Decent finish, though maybe a little watery for the style.

Very faint aroma, almost none.  Flavor is a little light for a dunkel but whats there is good.  Nicely balanced. Smooth, watery and refreshing.  Not bad.  A little more pricey than I would prefer to pay for a beer of this class at $7.49 a sixpack.  Total Wine.
Bottle. Rich, dark brown color. Creamy head. Tastes and smells of roasted malt. Feels good on the tongue. One of my favorite German beers. Looks great in my Warsteiner glasses.

At Richmond Oktoberfest 2006.  Excellent pour, lovely clear brown colour.  Lasting tan head, typical malt aroma.  Very drinkable, great palate and a surprisingly refreshing malt flavour. (!)  Delicious.
Bottle. Pours dark caramel, off white head. Aroma is malt, grass, and caramel. Flavor is   the same.
Clear deep brown body with a small light brown head. Sweet dark malt and molassas aroma. Sweet dark malt flavor with some molassas and caramel.

Pours a dark red or tan.  Subtle aroma, lacy head.  Flavor is slightly nutty, a little chocolate, with a good balance of sweetness.  The body is very light with not too much carbonation.  At $5 for a 12 pack, I could drink a lot of this.

Bottle 48F Lager Glass. Nice rich malty aroma, with sublte noble hops, a bit roasty very pleasent. Pours a dark red with a light tan head and decent lacing. The taste is a let down from the smell and look, just a touch of bitter roast, with very little hop presence, and very light on the tongue, really to light in my opinion.  A touch of metallic twinge. LIght palate quite disappointing.  Overall not too bad but to light on the tongue for a dunkel I think, but easily drinkable. A brew for the masses.
Bottle.  Pours dark amber, though taste is very light.  A bit sweet on first taste, nice hoppiness to the finish.  I have had a pretty decent range of tastes from this beer, depending on freshness.
Dark ruby brown color. You can smell and taste the roasted malt, but pretty light bodied.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber with a lacy off-white head. Aromas of nuts, hay and herbs. The body is light with soft carbonation. Taste is nutty, with hay, caramel and a bit of vanilla in the somewhat watery finish.
Nice label. Very good repeating beer. Nice dark beer with a transparent sight.  Very smooth while drinking out of my steelers mug. Finish has a little lasting slight malt or hop.

I was really disappointed by this beer, so much so that I think it may have just been a bad sample. I used to drink this occassionally, before I started rating and trying various beers, and I liked it. But I’ll go with what I had tonite.  Poured to a medium brown, with a very thin off-white head, that dissipated almost immediately, and left little lacing. Aroma was almost skunky, with just a hint of malt. Flavor was nothing special, and the finish was very dry. I will most likely try this one again just to give it a fair shot at redemption.
Moderately dark.  Slight charcoal taste.  Mildly sweet, but with a bitter aftertaste.
Deep brown in color.  Aroma does not represent the flavor.  Roasted chocolate taste.  I have seen it around a lot more lately, even at a wedding.  Good beer.

Pours very dark with a smallish head. Aroma is all malt with a hint of roasted chocolote.  Flavor is mostly sweet, but not overbearingly so. Roasted flavors of chocolate.  A mild hop bite helps to balance this beer. A bready aftertaste follows, and lingers long enough to make you want another sip.  I enjoyed this beer very much.

On tap at the castle on King:

Tapped a lustrous chestnut color....small off white cap lasts a while then reduced to a surface lace.

Good dose of Dunkel aromas: Sweet bread and cocoa some toastyness, light herbal sharpness.

Medium-light bodied, fair Munich malt spine, buttery mouth feel, smooth rounded character.

Up front you get to chew on some delicious dark Munich malt with its bready-sweet cocoa notes then the herbal spalter hops kick in to balance...mid palate there are some nutty tastes giving a sort of a liquid brownie when the cocoa malts meet the nut tones....medium finish...clean, malty, lightly bittered with herbal tones and a bready aftertaste.

A good solid commercial German dunkel...no surprises...om the light side for a dunkel but very drinkable and pleasing.

Had on tap at dunleaveys. Pours a dark red, some what good head. Smells  faintly of fruit and skunkyness. Tasted a bit of caramel. It was just ok.
Solid aroma.  Taste didn’t quite match the aroma however.  Easy drinking and unoffensive
Very light taste for a really dark beer.  Very light head, and very little to no aroma.  The beer goes down really smooth.  No lingering aftertaste with a really good flavor.

Pours a dark amber brown w/ medium semi creamy froth. Aroma of fresh leathered malt and hay. Medium nectar w/ mellow residual effers. Flavors are full yet soft. A roasted malty sweetness w/ slight coffee bean and caramel fnished off w/ a nice bittering to leave you readyfor the next sip. I really enjoyed this brew. Good stuff.
I thought this was a very tasty beer.  Reddish-black in color. Slight spicy maltiness with clean finish. Traditional dark brown German lager. Very drinkable.

Pours brown with an off white head. Aroma is faint so faint I cant’ get a good read of what it is. Taste is of wood and earth wich was kinda interesting i guess. Like the rater before me I too detected no hops. Malts make themselves known and a thin mouthfeel.
Bottle, poured brown with a quickly diminishing off white head.  Taste is malty with little to no hops detected.  Nice light bodied easy to drink beer.

Brown but translucent body with almost no carbonation or head.  Interesting smell.  Roasty and caramel dominate.  Tastes very roasty with caramel and coffee notes.  Very very good.  Well balanced despite the presence of afformentioned flavors and scents.  Pretty good for a lager.
Not an overpowering dark beer, even has abit of hop aftertaste, nice, easy drinking brew.
got at old chiago.  again not sure if their product gets to much light, had a skunk twist to it.  malt and sweetness, just off a little.

On tap in a Kings pint. Small head, fell quickly to nothing. Not even surface bubbles. Too dark to determine clarity. A solid middle-of-the-road lager. Comparable to Mexican dark lagers, but slightly maltier.

Pours brown with very small off-white head.  Nose is creamy, sweet, nutty.  Flavor is as well, too sweet for my taste, and a touch of off flavor - old bottle maybe?  Rather musty, not as clean as I expect a dunkel, and some fruity flavors as well.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Dark brown with red highlights and a puffy brown head. Aroma is slightly malty with some vegetable hints. Taste is sweet and malty with some caramel at the end. A bit watery but not a bad beer if you want to have a few.
Better than the regular lager but still not worthy enough to give it a decent rating. The malt and seem to be slightly inferior. An a beer to avoid if you can
Bottle. Dark brown color. Medium head that doesn’t last long. Malt,caramel,spices aromas. Caramel,malt and tofee tastes. Very enjoyable beer.
on tap: this is a nice straightforward dark beer.  not too unique, but good nevertheless.     seemed very compatible with the irish food i was having at the time.
Does the whole " no time to waste on cheap beer" ad apply to this?  Pours dark brown w/o much head.   A clean aroma and taste, nothing stands out.  Fairly blah.

On tap, I really wasn’t impressed with this beer.  Pours black, with very little head that dissipates quickly.  Very weak in the nose, and not much to write home about as far as taste either.  Bland and watery come to mind, with some light chocolate and lighter caramel flavors.  Not impressed with this one.
Decent brew... a bit of a caramel in the flav.     A drinkable but not very memorable brew.

Pours a dark brown, looks like a cola. Strong malty, yeasty aroma with a hint of chocolate. Thin off white head. Watery with not alot of pop except at the end. Would be good to cool down a spicy dish. Clean finish.

Six pack bottles sampled. Pours brown with a small quickly dissapating white head. Aroma of caramel malts, spices, toffee, and chocolate. Flavor is caramel, toffee, chocolate, and slight bitter hops. Thin watery body, but drinkable.
In Weimar, Germany.  Bottle.  Poured dark brown with a medium head.  Aroma of malts dominate.  Lighter tasting than it looks. Decent mouthfeel.  OK, but not outstanding.

Dark brown with nutty chocolate aromas that are not backed up by as much flavour as you’d expect. Pretty thin malt character, and thin in the mouth overall actually. Definitely not my favourite dunkel.

Loved this one.  Dark brown, translucent, minor white head.  Delicious taste of roasted coffee, balanced with a wheaty mellowness.  A terriffic beer for all seasons.  Not heavy as to be a bogging-down beer.
Pours dark brown with almost no head. Very flat with decent taste. I actually enjoyed this beer because it is very different but has a chocolate/ toffee taste with a strange buttery after taste.
Poured a mahogany clear color with a cream colored head.  Sweet roasty malt aroma and flavor.  Flavor had light chocolate and toffee notes.  Nice clean finish.
Bottle. A good Dunkel. Clean tasting, but flavorful. Roasty, but not overwhelmingly so.
Deep brown/amber, clean dry malt flavor, medium body, robust hop presence. Roasted biscuit flavor on a dry malt background. A nice beer.

Pours dark amber with a thin, mostly receding off white head. Aroma of toasted malt, light bread, and caramel. Taste is sweet chocolate and caramel malt, with a bit of chewiness for added body. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lively carbonation. A clean and drinkable dunkel.

Bottle and served in a big ole stein: Poured a rich mahogany hue topped a fading frothy beige head and okay lace. The nose is a weak characterisctics of caramel, toffee, walnut, allspice, and grassy hops. The taste clean blend of malt and noble grassy hops balanced sweet and bitterness. Sadly for the balance there is little depth. A session Dunkel bier I guess. There is a note of a vegetal flavor on the aftertaste which is lightly distracting. The mouth feel is fizzy and watery. I too was left wanting more, an almost macro dunkel, sad.

12oz, <!-- i -->Best before end: 11.Nov.06<!-- /i -->.  Pours a clear mahogany with a tiny light beige head.  Aroma of toasted malts, nuts, biscuits.  Taste is very nutty and biscuity, with a little bit of sourness toward the end.  Slight bitter chalky finish.  Light bodied, soft carbonation.  Not a bad beer.

Mixed reviews on this one. No strong aroma and the beer wasn’t as thick as I was expecting. Enjoyed it more on draft than I did in the bottle (the latter, which took on a slight grassy taste). I was left wanting more from this German dunkel, but would have one again.
Delicious.  Tastes of hops, roasted coffee, chocolate, and spices.  Scents of a lager (malt, hops) and chocolate.  Very unique and drinkable.

This beer pours a dark brown/amber color with little to no head.  There is a very strong smokey, malty smell and flavor.  This is a very smooth but not very complex beer.  This beer is easy to drink and I would probably have it again.  Cheers!
Had it on tap, pours dark brown with a light brown, creamy head. Some hints of sweet hops, light for a German Dunkel.
Relatively good.  Can’t say it was bad, but just tasted like a standard hoppy, light caramel/chocolate flavor, I did enjoy it though.
Very lagery, munich type aroma, with a touch of roast. Flavor is thin lager yeast, veggies, pumpkin.
Wow!  What a Treat!  Superb beverage.  As the bottle quotes ’life is too short to drink cheap beer’.  A must have with it’s dark tones and soothing character.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a small tan head. Aromas of toasted malt, hint of chocolate and light carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of toasted malt and carmel, light bitterness with a crisp clean finish.
Awfully light on flavor.  Not bad, but pretty mediocre as German beers go.  Light malt and a hint of hops.  Agree with frankenkitty on the touch of vegetal flavor.

Best by 06.JUN.2006    05a33


Clear sepia/cola brown with a thin cream-colored head. Light metallic notes and a touch of weak coffee in the aroma with caramel underpinnings and light sour vegetables. Stale caramel flavor with a sour finish. I fear this may be past its prime regardless of the fact that we’re well within the drinkability window. 



Single bottle from Cost Plus World Market, Orland Park, IL 60462

Pours deep, dark brown with a toamy tan head.  Unique aromas of kidney beans and southwest seasonings.  Flavor was nice... a clean, sweet caramel malt with a barely noticeable bitterness on the backend of the pull.  Almost reminded me of a sweet nut-brown ale.  Everything comes together nicely, with mildly sweet aftereffects mingling around with a light astringency, bitterness growing in the finish.  A nice medium-caramel mouthfeel accompanies the whole experience, and trust me, the experience begs another!  Very well-balanced brew.

Pours dark brown / amber with a tannish head.  Arorma is toasted musty malt.  Medium bodied with light carbonation - some oily aspects as well.  Taste is roasted malts, oatmeal aspects then dark caramel flavor.  Finish has a little bit of a hop bite, but it is mainly the malt that lingers through.  Light bit of astringency on the finish.  An okay beer, but I wouldn’t seek it out.

Bottle.  Toasted, starchy oatmeal and dusty malt nose.  Slightly prickly up front, rolls over the tongue a little caustic in texture, slightly sweet up front with a slightly spoiled taste over the middle, but smoothing out in the finish, leaving a oat, toast and (mildly) charred maple resin.
Other than just not looking good in a glass the 2x I tried this weekend. Toasted malt, clean, without the artificial caramel flavor I find in so many dunkels. All around very well made.

Pretty good.  Thought it would be a darker version of their pils and while it is it does have more.  Nice brown body w/ a tinge of tan in the head.  Some malty sweetness balanced okay w/ a light hop presence.  Not anything over the top, but well enough for what it is.

bottle - Pours brown with a moderate head.  The smell is mostly roasted malts.  The smooth, moderately thick palate brings in the nice roast malt flavors in this simple but fairly tastey beer.  It’s not great, but it is a solid session beer.
Average in its color with a normal brown. Aroma is soft with a light touch of malt. The flavor is weak with minimum notes of caramel and malt. Not  memorable dunkel in mu opinion.
Nothing outlandish in this beer. It tastes and smells of roasted malt. A decent that didnt stick around for to long. Dark ruby color. Tasted a bit bitter sweet. Very easy drinking. Hops are light.
Slight metallic taste and smell.  A little thin and bland.  Really nothing distinctive.

bottle : deep cherry wood or mahogany color. decent head with big fat bubbles, but pretty short-lived..leaves a nice ring though and a tiny bit of lacing..moderate carbonation. aroma is of mildly smoky malts (reminiscent, to me, of a smoked turkey at thanksgiving). flavor has a slight smoky quality to it and a hair of nuttiness as well

Very light smell, kind of weaker in color then i expected. The taste more then makes up for that, and that what counts in my book. Its not a heavy beer, but it has a nice acidic, malty taste. The aftertaste is supreme. I stil think Sam Adams black lager is better then this. I like it though, alot.

we used to drink warsteiner by the pitchers at one of our favorite watering holes...$5.oo cant go wrong.  its an aquired taste has a bit of a metallic taste.  less alcohol then expected and a bit thin.  roasted malt knocks a bit but not forbidding.

The Dunkel (dark) Warsteiner is better than the Premium Verum. I first had this at the OKtoberfest in Cincy and had so many it took me a few years to give it a try. Smooth, heavy on the palate, and slightly effervescant with a lingering after taste.
Pours a dark light brownish black with heavy carbonation.  Faint aroma of sweet malts and hops.  Flavor follows aroma... seems very thin.  Refreshing, but disappointing.
Bottle: A darker version of the original Warsteiner, falls bit short on overall taste and I would expect more body from a dunkel, too light.

You can never go wrong with the price!  This dunkel lager is a must to try if you enjoy any German beer.  Although my true preference is a strong doppelbock, a flavorful warsteiner lager is always a good choice for an afternoon drink during any season.
good it is very thick and DARK very dark it is a great beer for the winter/fall season.

Odd pour that looked remarkably like a cola, including carbon bubbles.  Thin head that lingers (again like a cola).  Weak scent.  Highly carbonated.  Watery bubly taste with some maltiness.  Very easy to drink, would be good for an all nighter session.

Draught. Pours cherrywood color with off-white head. The aroma is malted wheat with a touch of soap. The flavor is earthy and flowery hops, cream, burnt sugar, some leaves, and a decent malty body. Not too bad.
Not too bad a brew, tho the word bland comes to mind. Malty and caramel-y, a good dark brew, especially in the US.
Bottle.  Light brown colored pour with medium head.  A malty fruity aroma.  Not too bad.
Bottle:At first smell definate hops, but second smell has a hint of sweetness.  Roasted malt and chocolate.  Nice sweet short lasting finish.

Draught at Tyler’s in Durham, NC. Clear brown color with thin off white head. Metallic hop nose with molasses and chocolate undertones. Malty caramel flavor. Slightly sweet with a nice brown sugary cereal aftertaste.
not a bad dark brew, just not my flavor. Had a clean finish with a nice length.
this brew made me feel like i had a bird on my shoulder and pete kept calling me captain mcdunkel

Dark in color.  Light fading head.  Smells of hops and has quite the hop related bite.  Tastes of grains are apparent.  Pretty clean finish.  Good for a dark, but not impressive.  Is so hoppy I’m confused to a point.
one of my favorites, introduced to me by one of my german friends who is crazy about his beer.
I like Warsteiner light but not the dunkel.  Too hoppy for a dark beer.  Not impressed.

"Medium brown to dark brown color. Medium fluffy head. Has very mild aroma of any kind, hint of malts. A medium/light bodied dunkel. Has a hint of choclate and mild hops flavor. Very nice balance of the 2 Has a creamy mouthfeel, but is a little thiner then i expected. Over all good dunkel."

From Bottle



Poured medium dark with ruby highlights. 2 inch thick white foamy/creamy head. Fruity aroma. Flavor was malty and earthy (mushroom tones), not what I was expecting, was it skunked? Taste wasn’t offensive Carbonation was good, Mouthfeel was light.

Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is dirt, malt, and oreo. Smooth sweet somewhat malty. Has some caramel taste to it as well as cookie dough. A little nuttiness and some chocolate. All the flavors are subtle and sweet. Very smooth, could use more body.

Bottle.  Nutty dark malt and caramel aroma.  Dark reddish brown color with slight head.   Nice complex flavor for the style - hazlenut initially followed by caramel malt and ending with a mixture of chocolate and hops.  Nice mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation.  A very good dunkel that should be easily assessible

12 oz bottle in a motel room in Sandusky, OH.  Dark caramel with a small lasting head...dry, roasty-grainy aroma, surprisingly fresh but unimaginative...body a bit earthy and herbal, again fairly dry...mouthfeel fairly bland and rather watery.
Poured a nutty brown with a small bubbly white head.  Malty aroma.  Some malt in the beginning and very light hops at the finish.  A little watery.  Ok, not offensive, drinkable.

mild caramel presence on aroma with some floral hops. Falovr was mainly watered down sweet malts.  it was very very light on the palalte expected a little more body too it.  poured a brown hue looked like flat rootbeer.

Poured very dark brown with small bubbly head.  Leaves nice lace.  Aromas of floral hops, herbs, citrus, grass yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor is bright, crisp and clean, with complex undertones of grain, citrus, noble hops and fruit.  Nice dry finish.  Was a perfect complement to my Christmas duck.

Bottle in a loud, dark indie rock club. Dark semi bitter malts. mostly caramel with a metallic sort of reflection. Not too good on the dunkle tip. Kinda like cookie tasting but not quite cookie dough. Its an easy drinker, not bad...but not great.
Pours a dark brown/black with off-white head. The aroma is light, cookie dough and caramel. The flavor is also light, malty, semi-sweet caramel and toffee. The mouthfeel is thin and watery.

Bottled.  Very light, malty aroma of chocolate chip cookies (bready with a hint of chocolate) and a bit of rusted metal and then finally some caramel.  Dark cherry wood in color with a thin, white head that dissipates except for a ring around the edge of the glass.  Thin, metallic flavor with a touch of grassy, skunked hops.  I let this warm up for an hour and it still just doesn’t taste that great.  Not as metallic and more caramel as it warms, but still not complex.  Watery texture with a thin, crisp finish.
Draft - A nice Dunkel.  After I let it warm a bit the roasted malt flavors came through.  Not the best I’ve had, but good.

Decent dark body, good roasty aroma and flavor. Very clean on the pallete though. I woudln’t turn down another, but I wouldn’t seek it out either. It just didnt’ have enough complexity to it to keep my interest.

Bottle at Maker’s, OKC: poured dark brown with a small off white head. Another beer served too cold in Oklahoma. But that didn’t stop me from enjoying it. After warming up, lightly roasted malt and hops became apparent in the aroma. Mild malts in the flavor with a short sweetness. Lightly roasty. A pretty decent beer.

On tap at Fox & Hound in Southaven, MS of all places.  If you’re in the area, they have the best draft and bottle selection around (Except for the saucier, or course)  Anyway, about the beer.  It has a lingering burnt, hoppy flavor at the end.  Not my favorite kind of beer, but I liked it.  Decent aroma, flavor, and head.  Nothing earth-shattering, but it sure beats a Bud Light any day!

On tap at Pub Italia, Ottawa. Nice dark brown body with a thin off-white creamy head. Fair malty aroma that unfortunately lacks strenght and complexity. Its malty/hoppy taste is well balanced and carries roasty hints. Ends with a decent bitter/roasty finish.
Translucent brown pour with thin head that quickly dissipated. Weak to moderate aroma of caramel malts. Sweet flavors of toasted malts and caramel. Thin body, carbonated sipping.

Clear brownish red, almost no head to speak of. Light bodied with moderate carbonation.  Roasted caramel malt and coffee flavors.  Hint of hop bitterness on the back end.  Tastes like a good session beer to me.
Mug at Old Chicago had no head, but this probably shouldn’t be held against the beer. Nice clear brown color. Toasted malt taste that gives way to molasses and coffee finish. Sweet thick palate.
A bit of a carmel taste.  Does not have the bitter finish.  However, the taste is not as smooth as I would like.

I’ve found this Dunkel to be more flavorful on tap rather than in the bottle, but both ways are somewhat dissapointing. I love the appearance of this, but the taste is somewhat of a letdown with almost sour notes of caramel/maple.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head that quickly fades to a thin film.  Aroma is of malts and nuts with a funky sourness to it that seemed a little off.  Taste is of malts and herbal tea followed by mild hops.  Not a negative brew but my scratch will be better spent elsewhere.
Dark pour with small head.  Looks rich but taste is rather light and nondescript.  A little sweet carmel with a bitter side but not much.

355ml brown bottle split with gilvanblight. Dark brown in colour, thin layer of white surface foam. Almost no aroma, slight dark malt notes if anything. Taste was dark malt with slight roast bite. Thin body, high carbonation.

Tap at Oktoberfest in Oldsmar.  Poured out of the pitcher a nice dark brown with a bit of red and had a large tan head, but I think that was because they had just tapped the keg.  The aroma was sweet caramel malt.  The flavor was mostly sweet malt laced with caramel, chocolate and a bit of coffee even.  It was medium bodied on the palate, with the right amount of carbonation.  My rating may be a little high because we drank far too many of these as we enjoyed a great Oktoberfest celebration.  I’ll look forward to it again next year.

Pours dark with a hint of redness.  Head is off-white to a very light brown.  Aroma is roasty with something skunky about it.  Tastes somewhat bitter but goes down with a small hint of coffee.  An average beer overall.

Pours without much of a head and quickly dissipates.  Color is dark brown.  Nose is of caramel.  Taste is sweet, malty, light roasted coffee flavors.  Finish is slightly dry with some hop bitterness.  It does bite a little, seems like there might be too much artifical carbonation?  I’m not even sure that they add extra carbonation, but it seems that way to me.  It’s not a bad beer, just not very complex.  It is easy to drink however and makes a nice session beer.

Pours a dark cherry color with quickly disappearing head.  With no head, aroma is lacking but a little hint of syrup.  Flavor is sweet, syrupy with berries in the background.  If it were socially acceptable, this beer might go well with pancakes.  I’m usually not a fan of high carbonation, but this one goes flat quickly, leaving the taste a little watery.  For me, very middle of the road.

Bottle.  Pours like cola, dark brown with a quick little head.  Aroma has a little metal and a little funk (but not in a saison-good-funk way)  Flavor is sweet with malt and nasty with rusty metal.  I guess they went above the call of duty on that one.  Anyone can throw metal in there, but to use rusty metal ... sheer genius.  Not one I’d like again.
On tap at the Virginia Beach Brewfest. Dark brown with an impressive white head. Weak coffee taste, with a hop bite at the end. Smooth palate - not bad, but not something I’d seek out.

On tap at the local Old Chicago, Coralville, IA. The body is a very dark brown with some red showing through. The aroam had bubblegum and some fresh grass. There was also a little bit of hay. The taste is slightly dry with some light tobacco and hay. Finishes with funky mushrooms and bread. I like this one as a session beer.

12 oz bottle consumed In Wings in Myrtle Beach SC.  Pours brown with a short offwhite head.  Aroma is brief coffee and small hops.  Flavor is very similar.  A bit of chocolate as well.  Palate is thin and watery as expected from a dunkel.  Drinkable but not worth seeking out in the future.
Roast grain and coffee aroma. Truely brown color with a thin head. Sweet with a light coffee flavor and a hint of bitterness. Lacking in body. Somewhat one dimensional.
Nothing wrong here. It is a lager and its a good lager. Sweet and smooth, malty grainy taste.

Fairly thick, off-white head that left very little lacing on the glass.  Aroma consists of some chocolate, caramel, and just a hint of ass.  You can tell before you drink this beer that it’ll be alright, but not worth getting another sixer of.  Bitter at the start, but sweetening towards the finish, which is the only thing that makes this beer drinkable.  The palate is a little thin, but not horribly so.  All in all, a beer that is not really worth having around one’s refrigerator.
Draft.  Light caramel malt aroma, maybe some hops.  More of the same for flavors, with a distinctive acidic/sour note added.  Thin, mediocre.

Everytime I buy this beer it seems different.  Sometimes it has a great head, and sometimes it seems to have no head at all.  It doesn’t have much of an aroma at all, but it has a nice smooth, rich, and almost chocolatey taste.

The aroma is sweet with hints of hops and paper. The appearance is chocolate brown and the head is small and goes away fast. The flavor is not bad save the saltiness. Nothing really stands out, except the saltiness, as exceptional good or bad. Its pretty typical for a Dunkel. A caramel sweetness and a roasted malt. The hops have an astringent bitterness that hits you in the finish. Palate is somewhat watery but somehow it avoids being too weak. If you are looking for a really good Dunkel you could do better but it is not a terrible beer.

On Tap, Ciro’s.  Dark brown pour, slick little tan head.  Mild cola like sweet malt aroma.  Thin mouthfeel.  Taste is slightly sweet malt, but very thin and watery.  Drinkable, but pretty average stuff without a lot of character.

Draught.  At Ciro’s.  Poured dark reddish black (almost opaque) with a small light brown head.  Aroma very sweet malt with curious notes of grapes, cereal grains, burnt candy and a tiny harsh metallic  tang.  Taste is also grapey, with mild roast malt, almost root beer sweet, a bit sour on the finish - a bit of dry staw flavour on warming.  Mouthfeel is thin and a bit flat and minerally.  Keep it cold and it’s decent, but nothing to get excited about - it’s just a dunkel, after all ...

Bottle: A burnt sienna color with a quickly diminishing light brown head.  Through my August allergies, I noticed up on aromas of sweet malts like polished shoe leather with a thin coating of sorghum.  The feel is thin and pleasant.  The taste isn’t spectacular, but not bad either.  It is refreshing and has a wheatty aftertaste.  It seemed to have lots of carbonation.  I would prefer a little more in the initial aftertaste.  It is like you have to wait about 15 seconds before you are invited to take another drink.  I like the invitation right away and then if you resist, to have it followed by the lingering aftertaste.  Dunkels are to light for my tastes, but I can enjoy one every now and then.

If you like bitter beers, this is not quite what you’re looking for.  This beer is very smooth and flavorful (chocolate and a bit nutty).  I had it at the local bar and decided to buy a 6-pack later in the week.  It’s not bad (regardless of what its overall percentile tells you.  Try it out.
A nice body with a nice color, but a small head.  The beer has a sweet taste to it.  And the after taste is good not too bitter.
Not bad.  Warsteiner Pilsner is better but hey, good beer.  I would buy it again.  The carmamel flavor adds alot to the flavor.
Good walnut color, alcoholic and caramel aroma. No hoppiness in the smell. Faint hop taste, very nutty and malty. Overly alcholic taste with hint of banana. Overrated, generally.
Bottled. Pours a dark brown color. Light roasted malt aroms. A hint of some sourness as well. Light, somewhat watered down flavor. Drinkable, but not great.
Not bad.. I will drink again.. I have to, I bought a 12 pack.. ..  This was a little too nutty for me, but still a bargain at $10 / 12 pack AND a $2 mail in rebate!
A nice brown with a light brown head.  A malty aroma with a hint of hops.  Starts of with a hoppy bitterness and finishes with a malty sweetness.
Pours medium brown with a good beige head.  Malty and a little nutty in both the aroma and flavor.  Lightly hopped, medium carbonated, and pretty drinkable.

Sweet and nutty, a very clean drink - doesn’t get too clingy with either the sweetness or the yucky lager aftertaste.  Distinct cocoa. Hard to find a mass-market dark German brew in a brown bottle.   Mouthfeel was substantial, but didn’t become weighty after 3 or 4.  Nothing earth-shaking, but this is a good value at $7/6 in the local grocery store.

Pours a clear bubbly brown with a small amount of quickly dissapating white fizzy head.  Aroma is sweet malts, a little bit of nuts, and a sweet grass undertone.  Flavor is very thin, dry, grassy, and not the sweet malty nutty flavor I had hoped for.  This seriously tastes more like a slightly sweet pale lager than a dunkel. Overall, dissapointed.
Bottle.  Pours rich brown, sweet malt aroma.  Nice and smooth, a real drinker. I want to find this at $24 a case like one of the other reviewers!
Big fan of this classic. Great sweet, malty taste and aroma to this brew. It has a soft fnish and doesn’t leave any bitter aftertaste.

Cheers to the boys at the Keaton for beinging this in! Pours a dark brown body with a finger of mocha coloured head that lasts. Aromas are nutty, mild coffee, malty. Taste is sweet nuts, malt, and some mild bitterness. Finish is creamy, smooth, with a mild bitter finish. A decent brew!

A nice, light dunkel that could be enjoyed like a session beer.  Pours a decent brown with a decent head.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, and the taste is a bit subdued but that doesn’t stop this from being a good middle-of-the-road beer.  Nice hints of yeast, nut, and caramel are in the flavor, just not as prominent as in a higher quality dunkel.

Draft.  Dark brown body, thin white head.  Pretty average flavor: dark roasted caramel malt, bit of soapy hops in the ifnish.  Medium-thin mouthfeel.  Light version of the flavor in the aroma.  A perfectly nice beer, just nothing remarkable.

Pours dark amber in color with no head. Aroma is burnt malt/grain. Flavor is all residuel sugar, but weak. A little thin on the palate also. Has always been a "look I’m drinking good beer" beer at our local pub. Go figure.
Pours dark brown color, flavor is a bit nutty and sweet with little in the way of hops bitterness.
Pours dark brown with a long lasting head. Finish is a little bit strong. Bought for $24 a case in PA, good bang for your buck.

Bottle.  Pours nut brown to mahagoney with some brown head as it pours then completely dissipates.  Aroma is caramel and brown sugar malt with a light chocolate nose.  Initial flavor is fizzy caramel malt, slightly toasted.  Finishes a little hoppy and spicy with faint chocolate notes.  Medium bodied and fizzy palate, warming.
Dark brown with light malt aroma.  Has a thick mouthfeel.   Kinda sweet.  Above average for those cheap european beers that you can buy at the grocery store.

On tap: A dark lager for a nonstout -although I must admit I am unfamiliar with dunkels.  Thought it had a nice taste to it (earthy with undertones of caramel and fruit) ...nothing spectacular, but enjoyable.  The head was very nice.

Bottle into tulip glass.  Clear amber brown in the glass with a white fizzy head of medium size, diminishing to a dusting of bubbles in teh center with a ring on the edge.  Lacing is ok but oily; great sub-surface "racing."  Yeasty smell with notes of wet green grass; pilsener hops; fresh and earthy overall.  Taste was of fructose, prickly acid turning tangy; like a honeydew melon.  NO bitter in the hops.  Some stickiness in the finish, which was also dusty and smoky malt.  Prickly nature might have been roast malt.  Smooth and drinkable with a light to medium body.

An even flavored light nutty beer.  A hint of carmel, it’s very light on the palate.  No bursting of flavor here.  It’s smooth but nothing extraordinary.  I drank this beer around 55F to get the most of its flavor.  Not a favorate but I wouln’t pass on it.
Somewhat dark brown color. Nutty sweet aroma. Flavor is about the same. A simple but pleasant beer. Nothing exceptional, but i wouldn’t complain if you passed me one.

The bottle poured a dark reddish brown liquid with an off-white rocky medium head that lasted for a short time and dissipated almost entirely leaving almost no lacing. The aroma is light and fruity. The sweet malt comes through nicely. The taste is delicate and slightly bitter. There are initial notes of coffee and chocolate. The finish is long-lasting and also a bit bitter.
Poured clear amber.  Head was nice and long-lasting.  Beer had a hint of a skunky aroma.  Had a clean, smooth taste.  Good beer.

Thin/clear mahogany, iced-tea like colored body. Head is very large and gorgeous, very light brown and builds with the reverse waterfall look like a guiness. Smell is of light fruit malt, very clean and with nothing else. Taste is a little watery thin gets complex with smoked bacon, blood, dates, raisins and trace metallic flavors. Very interesting and certainly more complex than what I was expecting. Aftertaste is ham and maple syrup. Not bad

i had this on tap.. dark brown clear pour, with a tinge of red. a small white head. grainy aroma, not much of note. flavor is a slightly sweet crisp malty flavor, with a tiny bit of bitterness.  pretty thin mouthfeel. drinkable but unremarkable
Good beer as far as taste but didnt have a good long lasting head.  Poured a jet black.  Tasted a little hint of raisin.

In the bottle. Dark, but not too dark. Has a white head, but not too much of a head. Aroma is lager -like, but not too impressive. Flavor is rich toffee-like roasty lager blend, but not too flavorful. I guess my point is that this beer is OK, but just not very memorable. The dunkels vom fass are way way better, but maybe bottled german beers that find their way to Nebraska have a low ceiling and a large age.
Pours with a foamy head from the bottle.  Very dark in color.  No flavors or aromas are recognizable above the grain.  A good taste, a bit watery, but better than most macro beers.   A decent finish.

Aroma isn’t impressive.  I smell grain.  Flavor has a decent amount of grain and is a little sweet.  A little maltiness.  Thin bodied.  The overall flavor and aroma reminds me of a pilsner that I had the other day...lots of grassy taste.  It’s alright, but I’m not a fan of a grassy taste.

Tap at Ciro. Pours deep clear red mahogony with a short scummy white head. Lightly sweet toasted malty aroma with some apple and chocolate. Sweet. Some smoke. Wheaty, apple and raspberry tartness.  Burnt sugar and cider vinegar. Lightly spiced. Finish is bland and watery.

On tap at Gustav’s restaurant. Pours a dark mahogany with a tall white head, very stable. Clean sweet malt aroma, hints of caramel and light chocolate, layers of grain. Finish had a light touch of hops, left it trailing a bit sweet. Over all not a bad dunkel, but not one of my favorites.

Its dark brown with a nice white1" head.
Gainy aroma with a little roast.Taste caramel and cereal (cheerios) light body
I thought it really clean no off flavors
or aromas.Try it with mexican food OLE!
Bottle. Dark brown color with medium white head. Low malt aroma. Medium malty flavor with small finish. Drinkable pub brew.
not terribly impressive, looks  nice shade of dark brown, though flavor is rather light and the mouthfeel is pretty thin, so overall impression..... eh
Watery brown colour, with odd old smell. Tastes like sucking on a piece of cloth. If you really need to drink. Very grainy
Tapped.  Dark brown with big white head (2-3 cm). Malty aroma with hints of caramel and citrus. Mainly malty taste with hints of roast. Semi-bitter aftertaste.

Bottle:  Nutty caramel aroma.  Pours a dark brown with red hilights when held to the light.  White head that lasts a minute or so.  Sweet caramel from start to finish, but increases slightly in the finish.  Toffee becomes noticeable in the finish along with some light hops.  There are some light Euro-lager flavors lingering in the background that I could do without.

Beautiful dark mahogany with a small, quickly disappating eggshell head. Lightly roasted nose with an additional aroma resembling saaz hops. Taste is of roasty malt, caramel and some hops; not much else really. Moderately sweet, not much bitterness detected in the aftertaste. Medium body with fizzy carbonation. No lacing or head retention. Overall, drinkable but nothing special.
A dark beer that drinks light but still with full flavor. One leads to another, this beer is good on a cold day served at 42 degrees. Can often find it on special for a good price as well.
Pours a dark crimson with hues of brown. Aroma is apples, and walnuts. Flavor is a little lacking, malts and a little nuttyness to it. Nothing special here..

Pours an auburn color with no head. 
Smells kind of sour & a little fruity.
Tastes nutty, slightly metallic, with an astringent like dry aftertaste.
Thin bodied drink with decent carbonation.
Nothing i’ve mentioned is overwhelming. All the aspects of this beer are subtle. Nothing really stands out. It’s fairly weak for a dark beer
This was really rather bland, I saw a dark beer and was expecting some flavor and there was none, won’t get again.
Bottle. Clear, dark amber color with a small off white head. Mild aroma of sweet malts. Flavor also is very mild, unfortunately. Some sweet maltiness and a touch of bittering hops, but not much else.
Easy to drink, but not particularly remarkable. Slightly bitter and malty at the same time. Not bad, but probably wouldn’t pay premium prices for it.
Pretty brown color and very smooth beer, but typical of many greman beer not a lot of body, malt, or hops.  Nice head but tast did not equal it appearance.
Pretty Brown Ale-like color. Tastes similar to a decent Vienna. Easy drinking and smooth, but being an import, probably not worth the premium...

Bottle from the corner Osama store.
Poured a dark almost black color with a nice head and fair lacing.
Aroma of sweet malt. Sweet malty flavor with a bit of chocolate at the finish, a bit to sweet for my tastes.
on tap, very dark, not much taste though kind of like a vienna.  what taste there is quite mild.  easy to drink, but dark enough to look cool in a beer bar.

Bottle.  From Bob in the 2004 Beer exchange.  Pours a dark brown that is completely clear, and a thick fluffy head that leaves in about a minute.  Nose of a light beer, a little sour maybe.  Initial flavor is malty and with light medium body.  A little metallic at first with a sweetness at its finish and slight hints of baker’s chocolate.  A very slight bitterness at its finish as well.  Nice lacing actually, considering how quickly the head disapated.  Not bad and this actually gets better as it warms.  I’d like some more body to it, but an ok quaff.

Rerate from December 2004.   Much better this time around.  In the 50th percentile, but if this were an Anheuser Busch brew everyone would be gushing about how good a beer they made for once.  Anheuser World Select is not good, and they try so hard.  This is good.

Deep brown to near-black in color, fine off-white head , but leaves very quickly. Soft, sweet aromas, hints of cocoa, raisins, nuts. Slightly harsh initial mouthfeel, light body, minimal texture, a little gritty, a little flinty. Very little character in this beer , not quite the flavor or sweetness one usually finds in the better dunkels. Something’s missing, and we’ll freely quote from Homer Simpson. "Hello? Taste?"

Draught

Beautiful dark copper brown with medium off-white head. Lightly metallic, malty and smokey nose. Malty, quite thin with some hops shown in the finish. Lacks dunkel character, more like dark lager. 4/4/4/2/9 2.3

Draught@some pizzeria in Torino

Deep amber-copper color, small beige head. Caramelly-grainy aroma. Medium-bodied. Warming alcohol. Sweetish caramel, harsh hoppyness, bready. German version of Baltic dark lagers. 6/3/6/3/12 3.0
had this at german park for octoberfest.  tastes good, pretty strong. i really enjoyed it and would get it again.

Pretty weak in the aroma category...almost smells like their Verum, but not nearly as strong, no smell of roasted malts to speak of.  Looks nice, deep brown with a decent light tan head.  Nice flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee on top of the malts.  Not nearly as full bodied as a stout, as it should be, but a little bitter on the aftertaste. This beer is apparently the poster child for dunkel beers.  Much better fare than the Verum.  I would drink this again.

The Warsteiner crown is meant to impress on here, I suppose.  Aroma of... sardines and anchovies?  Strange to say, but distinct.  Black color, of course.  Fair looks to this babe.  Sips on it... reminds me of spring fields on rolling Appalachian hillsides.  Or something of the sort.  Not overly impressed, but reminded me I need to get back into them mountains for adventures.
Dark brown/garnet, smallish, frothy, tan/charcoal head.  Aroma faint but pleasant with sweet malts, light caramel.  Malty and nutty but light; notable nut/hop finish.  Thin.
This beer is okay until you drink it.  Not nearly as good as the original.  Can’t understand the ranking on this one.  At least I got a free glass.
nice straightforward german beer. clear brown color, not too heady. very malty, begins with a nutty taste, followed by the mealy aftertaste.

12 oz bottle, best before July 05.
Pours a clear dark brown with a small short lived tan head. Mininimal lacing.


Aroma was sweet, malty, caramel. A touch of chocolate. 

Taste is sweet, a touch roasty, a touch nutty. Body is thin and watery. 

Average.

Pours a chestnut brown with a small beige head.  Aroma was sweet, caramel, nuts.  Tad like a candy bar.  Lively carbonation, watery texture.  Medium bodied.  Tastes on the sweet side carried by the caramel and nut essence.
Bottle. Clear, dark brown with average head. Aroma is not heavy, faintly chocolate-malt. Relatively light bodied, finishes quickly, with maybe a slight hint of bitterness.

I actually expected more from  a famous name brewery. 
Small initial haed goes away quickly. Aroma, flavor, and color all middle of the road.
Sorry, but lots of other better brews out there to drink.
Very nice mahogany appetence with lasting head.  Flavor is somewhat malty but very thin.  No aroma.
niece dark thick brown colring with niece head very smoth malty aroma very good beer

Sweet caramel maltiness with mild spices. Pretty rich mahogany colour with ok lacing and a small head. Effervescent on tongue despite not appearing it would be. Malty throughout the thin mouthfeel, this was easy drinking and refreshing and had a long sweet finish.
beautiful dark pour with a thick creamy head.  Very appetizing appearance.  Not much in the aroma category, but quite the easy drinking brew.  I enjoyed it.
Pours dark with a small frothy head.Very easy to drink with a nice clean finish

Nice deep charred wood brown with off white head. Light malt and faint roasted notes on the nose. Light body with no finish. Light roasted flavor though really not a lot to it. Decent quaffer but the color doesn’t indicate anything as to the flavor.
hick, dark brown beer with a thick creamy head that disappears VERY quickly... Nice pour... Good color, tastes like it looks-dark and stormy with a hint of full-bodied excitement.

On tap this beer had a great head. The lacing was good, a bit different than i’m used to, it was very even. Although it was very clear, it was dark and I couldn’t see through it. The body was very thin, but they market it as light bodied. It was very clean tasting, but not very complex. It was a decent beer, but lacked in flavor.
this dunkel has a lite body, clear brown color & a nutty nose. not bad, not great. of the 3 Warsteiners I’ve had, it’s the best.

Representative of German style brewing, rather smooth body with a solid finish.  I always would drink this beer at this German restaurant we would go to.  Went great with the food.  I have not went out and bought a case of it before, so it’s not special enough to warrant that type of affection.  All-in-all though it is pretty good.

Dark Thick Brown Coloring With a Small Head.  Sweet and Malty Aroma. Some Roasts.  This Goes Down Amazingly Smooth.. Nice Rich Malts..Very Sweet...Bordering on Too Much..But This Is An Excellent Dunkel.
Dark brown with a slight white head.  Semi sweet, with a burnt sugar taste and a malty aroma smooth body and flavour.  Pretty decent!
Nice dark brown color with an off white head.  Has a slightly sweet roast malt aroma, mayhaps a touch of nuttiness.  Very smooth to drink.  No overwhelming flavors to speak of.  Malty.  Crisp finish.

Draft. Zum Limzer in Hamilton. Nice dark brown colour, with an excellent white head. Muted aroma of sweet malt. Nice dark maltiness, but a bit light in the body and the flavour. Very drinkable but uninspiring.
Nutty scent, nutty taste, a little tinny at the end.  Drinkable, perfect for this time of the year.
Pours a blackish color with little head.  Mild aroma of malt.  Taste is pretty weak: slim malts and barley.  Very watery.  Not offensive, but it doesn’t taste like much of anything.
Drinkable Dunkel with roasted malts and some smoked flavor.    Picked up a twelve pack for mass consumption at Wildwood, NJ’s annual Irish Fall Festival.
(bottle) dark, coffee colored...wheaty, roasted with a full mouthful yet still dry and drinkable... but then again after each beer rating it just seems to get easier and easier to throw ’em back.
Dark brown with a frothy white head. Decent body some roasted malt but not as much rust and smoke than I like from the style. Medium body, mostly dry finish.
Dark brown body with a tan head.  Malty aroma and flavor.  Noticed wheaty/barley flaovrs and it had a bit of a chalky feel to it as well.  Finishes medium and fairly clean.
Body is a deep amber/brown with minimal head formation.  Aroma is malty, but not very strong.  Flavor of roasted barley, caramel, and butterscotch.  Very drinkable.

Pours dark brown with red luster, minimal head that dissolves quickly.  Aroma is roasty with a hint of sweetness.  Initial taste is rather bland, with some roasted and caramel taste.  The body is somewhat thin with about as much carbonation as a soda.  The finish is rather bitter but ephemeral.  I prefer to drink it cold from a bottle when I’m looking simply to quench my thirst but I’m not in the mood for a pale beer.  Otherwise, nothing spectacular.

Poured a nice dark brown with reddish tinges, with a moderate head.  Fairly weak aroma dominated by sweet malts, with some yeasty, bready notes.  Very sweet flavor with good roastedness and nuttiness.  Mouthfeel is a little thin and watery, but not awful.  A real good beer, especially with I’m in the mood for something light and sweet.

Ultimately, too sweet of a dunkel, almost sugary. That’s what must be responsible for the slight hangover after only 3 of these last night. Some fair nuttiness in the aroma, and plasing meatiness in the mouth, and carmelized nut flavor, but too much and sticky at the end.
Reminds me of a weak English brown...sweet and nutty with a heavy malty aftertaste...I couldn’t drink 4 or 5 in a row though...

Had this one on tap at the Rathskellar in Rockford, Il in one of their fishbowl glasses.  It was a pleasent taste and easy enough to drink, I don’t really think ther was any thing special about this one though.

Now, in the commercial description, it says "A light bodied clean dark lager"  Now I’m all for dark, but the rest of it never really has impressed me with any form of brew craftmanship.  Just like this beer.  But maybe I’m just an scumbag.

Large tan/light brown head with good retention and lace. Clear mahogany color, good lookin brew. Faint malt nose, lightly nutty and doughy. Med/light body, lightly creamy mouthfeel. Medium dry malt flavors, caramel, moderately sour, with a touch of roast in the dry finish. Surprisingly drinkable!?
Draught. Dark garnet body with a one finger loose head. Grape and wheat flavors abound. Nice, but the grape flavor s a little overpowering.
When I took a sip, I wondered where the rest of this beer was but upon further tasting , I learned to appreciate.  Much lighter than I expected but was not disappointed.
far better than the Verum, malty scent w/hints of coffee, brownish hue, thin, slightly sweet & little coffee like taste to it, not a lot, i would buy this from time to time...not bad.
12 oz bottle at Eds:  full bodied, slightly sweet, slight roasted dark lager. Solid dunkel,  surprisingly good.
Pale malty aroma, somewhat benine.  Lightly sweet malty flavor throughout.  Thin mouthfeel though , somewhat smooth.  Has a  clean refreshing aftertaste. A decent dunkel just needs more oomph.

I’ve only found one place that carries this beer, it’s an ok beer. Brown beer with a light head, with hints of roasted malts and maybe some caramel in there. If I find a place that sell it I might pick it up.

Brown beer with a minimal head. Bready sweet aroma with a hint of roasted malt. Thin in the mouth, average carbonation. Tastes slightly sweet with a mild caramel flavor and enough hop bitterness to balance it out. No noticeable hop aroma or flavors. Very clean and easy to drink to the point of being forgettable.  Take it or leave it beer, will only buy on sale.

12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. Freshness date of 23 Feb 05. Still fairly fresh then, I guess.Poured out the color of brown shoe polish, with a minimal white head on it. Aromas are of roasted malts, some yeastiness, and not much else. I can barely detect a smattering of hops, but it is fleeting. Tastes are of malts, some coffee notes, yeast, and a slight, but quickly disappearing note of hops. Slightly bitter tasting, but it’s more from the malts than the hops. Mouthfeel is on the thinner side of things, kind of leaves you wanting and expecting something more. An ok beer at best. Not something I would go out of my way to find again, however.

Burnt amber body with a small white head. Aroma is full of roasted malt and lightly hopped. Flavor matches somewhat but has a lot more malt in the palate. There is a sweet yeasty flavor that comes out in the finish. Overall I think this is a good beer but I need more exposure to this style before I can finalize my opinion.

Dark copper rubyish color, thin beige cap, keeps a skim for a while, minimal lacing in small spots and strings. Aroma has a gentle but appealing dark bready aroma, very slightly sweet and tangy. Taste is quite mild with a slight lagerish twang of sweetness, weakened caramel and the mildest of mild roast. Clean, poofy thin body, not watery, just empty with some slight tangy sweetness and starch. I thought I was doing myself a favor picking this up on sale, but nah, not really. No where near what a good dunkel should be at.

Pours deep brown with a big off-white head and great lace.  Aroma of malt, some hops, toffee, and cognac.  Tastes malty, with some toffee, cabernet, and smoky qualities at the finish.  Mr. Beer below me should be booted from this site.  I’m willing to bet his name is Hyman Rosenberg.
Why were the NAZIS so mad? Because they were drinking bile! The Holocaust would not have happened if they had some good beer! Now you know what happens when you drink shit!

A nice dunkle, great flavor for a macro beer. Was consistently good both on tap and bottled. Pours dark and is malty and slightly sweet but a little thin. Has Much more character than regular warsteiner.

Pours reddish brown. Medium tan head. Aroma is slightly hopped and caramelly. Some definite malt aromas as well. The taste is like a caramelly version of the regular Warsteiner. It’s sweeter and less crisp and grassy. Not too bad, but only average. Mouthfeel is smooth enough and the finish slightly bitter, but this is essentially a macro dunkel. Drinkable enough but not complex.
Burnt coffee flavor. A little watery for a dunkel. It’s something I wouldn't stock. Just didn’t have that hook that made me jump at it.

this is a solid dunkel. consistent brown color with an enjoyable aroma that is slightly malty. has a slight fruity light raisin taste that is enjoyable, leaves a nice lacing on the glass, i will have agin
Dark brown body witha  few red hues. Foamy tan head. Sweet, nutty lager aroma. Rather plain nutty soft malt flavor with an insipid body. Overall rather mediocre.

Dark brown pour with a smaller head with nice lace. Caramel malts mostly, some roasted as well. Light hops in the nose. The flavor has mostly roasted malts, though the caramel shows through a bit. Slightly hoppy. Palate is watery, body a bit thin, finishing malty.

Dark brown/ruby red color with a nice looking whispy head and some good lacing. The aroma has some light dark caramel malts along with some fig and some saaz crispyness. The flavor is vaugely watery with some of the roasted malts coming through but still light like a lager. Not too bad. I’ll see how the rest of this sealed six pack is.
Far better than the Pilsener, dark pour, with slight chocolate/caramel aroma and flavor.  It’s not strong at all and easy to drink.

From a bottle... it poured a thick, long lasting, light tan head and possesed a very pleasant malt aroma. Yes, this is the "Bud" of Germany, an ultra-common workingman’s drink, but it is tasty... however, I’ve been known to overindulge with it before, and it WILL give you a nasty hangover!
a good all around beer.  i’ve been told many times that it’s the budweiser of germany...  lucky germans.

Smooth and light taste considering it was so dark. I was impressed by this beer expecting a gross, heavy taste.  The only problem with this beer was that it may have been a little on the watered down side.
Sour toasted malt aroma.  Nice burnt malt/hop flavor.  A little watery but still manges to stick to the tounge.

Very drinkable German import. Pours very dark brown and clear with little head that dissipates to a very thin to nonexistant line of foam. Hop aroma is lightly floral but is too mild to be noteworthy. Very malty and grainy, an exceptionally smooth mouthfeel with no hint of bitterness or roughness. Some coffee and caramel like undertones. A good well rounded and drinkable session beer.
Slightly chocalatey aroma. Malty flavor with hints of roastedness. Smooth and very easy to drink. Buying this by the liter is dangerous.

This was pretty much a cheap German lager with dark food coloring.  I didn't get much character out of this dunkel, although it was sweet.  Otherwise the aroma had hints of metallic hops.  A lame example; I'm surprised this is actually referred to as a dunkel on this website as it lacks character.
Thin and easy to drink.  Not very good though... it's there, but that's about it.
This beer was quite enjoyable and accompanied food well.  Good color and smooth.
I just like this beer. It has a nice color and malty aroma. Very drinkable.

On Tap. Copper/Brown with miniaml head.  Nothing distinct in the aroma (good or bad).  Tasted a little thinner than other Dunkels, but the lacking bitterness was welcome for me. Although lacking sophistication of any fruits or spices, this is a quality brew that is quite drinkable and clean.
Smooth, heavy on the palate, and slightly effervescant with a lingering after taste. Perfect for a quick swig or more studied enjoyment.
Great beer. I am new to drinking dark beers, but this is easy to take, has some interesting flavors and doesn't sit in the gut like a rock.
Black with a thin quickly discipating tan head. Lots of malts in the nose with the strange lager funk in the taste. Nothing too exciting overall.
Malty, sweet smell.  Slightest bitter flavor.  White head.  Overall a good beer.  Probably great with a spicy mustard brat!
Dark red with a tan head.  Nice malty aroma. Very nice flavor. Very good beer.

Light aroma; good looking; great taste--strong, dark, and German--what more could you want?  Good choice.***Re-rate: On a second go-round, I realize just how awesome this beer is.  Creamy and dark...so good.
Little more flavorful then Premium Verum.  Has a plesant aroma, taste, and look.  Readily available, and much more classy then the average "run of the mill" beers.  Good refreshing beer.

The aroma is not very noticeable. The beer is hefty. It looks delightfully regal, its bottle proclaiming it the Queen of the Beers in German. Its flavour and palate are full and satisfying, making this a beer of substance, and, quite possibly, my all-around favourite German beer. The Dunkel (dark) Warsteiner is better than the Premium Verum.
Good with a steak or something of the like.  Very simlilar to the premium verum.  hints of roasted malt perhaps.  Not great but certainly good.

Tastes as if they added dark food coloring to the regular Warsteiner. Roasted notes are very light in this beer, and altogether simply tastes like the Warsteiner Premium Verum. Low bitterness in the finish. Easy to drink, but a bit watery.

Had to pour into a different glass to get a good off-white head of foam going. Quickly dissipates. Body is dark brown and clear. Aroma is extremely light. Smells a little like pears and a little less like malt. Very tiny bubbles of carbonation add some to the mouthfeel, but that's all there is. Tastes watery, more sweet than bitter. Leaves a clean after taste, but doesn't encourage me to have another. Next?

Bottle.  Nice dark brown with tan head.  Sweet malty aroma.  The taste didn't quite live up to the appearance and arome for me.  It was a bit watery and didn't have all that much flavor.  It was ok I guess, but certainly not outstanding in any way.

Draft: Pours a rich dark brown with a thin tan head.  Musty hop and earthy malt aroma.  Body starts with some grainy off-flavors and finishes with a more authentic German flavor and some sweet, almost floral European hops.  This could definitely use some more balance and fresher ingredients.
Good aroma.  Full bodied.  Medium brown (deep) with adequate foam.  Slightly sweet taste.  Foam dissipates quickly.
Not good, but not too bad.  Won't have this one again.  A little sour and very thin body.
Listless roastiness amongst restless veggies...Pumpernickel crumbs drowning in weak, watery fizz...Campfire embers several days after being doused by heavy rains...
(bottle) Deep-medium brown with good off-white head. Mild aromas. Very little malt aroma. Mild malt flavors. A bit thin in body.
No strong flavors other than a metalic one. A very mainstream brew with no distinguishing qualities
POured a rootbeer color, little color.  ALmost no head,. Aroma is slightly skunked, floral.  Flavor is very watery, not living up to the dark color of this one. Wouldn't recommend it.

On tap at Gustav's Restaurant, Clackamas, Oregon.
Beer looks like a glass of black coffee with a tan head..by "black coffee" i dont really mean completely black..but a mahogany brown colour.
Smell was quite subdued..slight chocolaty style malts but not much.
Very thin and watery tatslessness..poor carbonation..flat horrid.
Thin and wat too watery on the tongue.
Not very drinkable at all..i wonder if there was some problem with the keg?
Average beer. Quick diminishing head, leaving very little lace.  Dark amber/ caramel tone.  First sips were the best, dimishing to a watery taste (despite the color).  Ehh.

Dark cola color to this no headed beer. Smells like water and malt. This really isn't a very good beer. The taste is slightly bitter and hardly that, caramel, water. Not a great dark beer at all. If Warsteiner is the Bud Light of Germany, the Dunkel must be the Amber Bock. Unimpressive beer to say the least. Germany has so much more to offer. Wow, tangy (sarcasm).

Dark caramel color with a creamy head formation and a malty aroma. The taste is slightly nutty, with hints of  caramel, a touch of chocolate, and fresh malts. Nicely balanced finish with a subtle touch of hops.
Subtle sweetness in the aroma and carries through this brew.  Finishes to the sweet side.  The verdict is still out on this one.

I had this on tap from Old Chicago over the Oktoberfest celebration.  I was quite impressed with this beer.  Although not "quite" as malty as I expected, it was very good.  The malt was balanced nicely by the hop bitterness, with little hop aroma.  The body was just a little bit light.  Overall, a very drinkable beer.
Small beige head atop clear mahogany body.  Aroma is sweet, nutty, and caramel.  Taste is caramel, nutty, mediuim sweet.  Medium body.

Draught at Old Chicago. Unsweetened molasses aroma at first whiff. Some sweetness emerges at second whiff. Clear dark reddigh brown in color. Small, off-white head that mostly diminishes. Not much lace. This is a maltfest. Significant alcoholic mouthfeel which is somewhat surprising given only 4.9% ABV. No bitterness whatsoever, although I suppose one shouldn't expect any from a German Dunkel. Not much sweetness making this a bit boring and one-dimensional.

Decent head that is creamy on top.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is a little earthy with some roasted malts.  Color is a nice dark brown.  Flavor is a little bland but refreshing for a dark beer with some more malts.  Finish leaves a slight metallic aftertaste but is smooth.  An ok dunkel but nothing special.
licorice, dry soy, not good.  ruby body, small white head.  dry, grainy, roastey and soy.  flat and funky

Dark brown in colour with a thin white head. Fragrant cherry/cranberry aroma with a perfect amount of maltiness. Light-bodied; Mild flavour, a bit of sweetness in the taste. Aftertaste mild as well, not showing much character. Overall, smells and looks much better than it actually is! I had this pint on draught at the Old Toad in Rochester, New York on 20-October-2003.
Quite uninspiring really, not very strong flavour and chemical aftertaste.  I was disappointed.
Poured a dark brown with almost no head. Aroma was faint and of malt. The flavor was smooth, but a bit thin. I had hoped for a more robust beer. Not bad, but I probably won't get it again.

Pours a deep reddish brown, with a loose off-white head. It exhibits good head retention and leaves a nice lace on the glass. Very hoppy, floral aroma with a hint of malt. The classic "beer" aroma . The flavor is rather light, with some hop bitterness on the finish with some roasted flavors. A slight metallic edge in the aftertaste gives me a somewhat "stale" feeling about the flavor. The mouthfeel is very light, while the large bubbles of carbonation give it a harsh edge in the mouth.
Decenct dunkle.Kind of typical/very smooth/nice buzz.Nice dark brew but the flavor can seem off a little off at times(soapy?)
